author: Facocero

description.text: The Snowflake Globe is a sphere made out snowflakes. The whole thing was made by translating, mirroring, and rotating shapes inside of loops. The snowflake I designed was projected out onto the surface of a sphere and rotated to each face of an icosahedron. There are 20 hexagonal snowflakes on the surface and 12 pentagonal spaces between the snowflakes. All of the design was done in BlocksCAD. The design was printed in a friend’s office at Western Washington University on a Flashforge Creator Pro (Thank you for the printing time Reza Afshari).

Printer Brand:

FlashForge

Printer:

Creator Pro

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.2 mm

Infill:

100 %
The design was printed on a Flashforge Creator Pro, using natural PLA filament. There were plenty of supports, but they all came out.

I had a great time designing for the BlocksCAD Snowflake Challenge and learning BlocksCAD. Trying different things was easy, and I learned how to make changes in my design by duplicating and collapsing blocks, and defining variables.

I parameterized 1/12 of a hexagonal snowflake to begin with. Spheres were translated inside a loop and hulled together to create each line. I parameterized each line by using the vector equation for a line r = v0 +t(v1 - v0), where v0 and v1 are the beginning and ending points of the line.

It was mirrored across the YZ plane and rotated inside a loop into the six points of a snowflake.

The whole thing was scaled up, the radii of the spheres were made larger, and a couple lines were disabled to make the design more printable.

The lines were all projected out onto the surface of a sphere. I gave them a Z coordinate by solving for Z in the equation of a sphere: x^2 + y^2 + z^2 = r^2.

I rotated and mirrored the snowflake to get four snowflakes that would be copied around the sphere to all 20 faces of an icosahedron.

To rotate around a line in the X-Z plane, I first rotated around the Y axis to get that line on top of the Z axis. Then I could just rotate around the Z axis alone. I found how much to rotate by calculating the dihedral angle of an icosahedron.

By rotating the snowflake in a loop around the Z axis, I was able to distribute 20 equally spaced snowflakes across the surface of a sphere.

license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
This fits the Cat5 RJ45 cable locks from Panduit.
You can't find the key by itself, and you have to buy a pack of connectors for $50 or more to get a key. This can get VERY expensive if you use these and lose or break a key.
This is not an exact copy of that key, but will work to unlock and lock those connectors.
Fits Panduit PSL-DCPL-C

The tip isn't easy to print and may require some tweaking to the settings to make it come out right.
I tried making a version where the tip prints Vertical, but the key is too weak when printed that way and snaps off in the lock. Print this laying down and it works.
The flat part under the tip is meant to snap off. It's only there to support it while printing.

title: Filament Spool Hub with Print In Place Bearings

description.text:
Hubs to hold your spool in typical 8mm spool holders with print-in-place roller bearings.

Update 1/23/18:
Apparently the spools are not as standard as I thought. Got a new one from 3D Mars and the hole was bigger. Use the original hubs for spools up to around 54mm and the large version for ones up to 57mm

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Clone

Supports:

No

Resolution:

I used 0.2 with a 0.3mm nozzle

Infill:

N/A

Notes:

The two hubs should be printed with the "flat" side down. You may need to use a raft if you get a lot of "Elephant Foot" on your first layer. The prints I have made usually needed to have a few of the roller bearings broken free so everything turns freely. If you have trouble with the bearing sticking together, try lowering the extruder temp and/or reducing the filament flow rate a bit.

I included a cover for the M8 nuts typically used. For these, pause the print at 6.8mm and drop the nuts in, then let it finish.

Assembly:

Press the hubs into the spool with the spacer between them on the threaded shaft. Snug up lightly with the knobs and place in holder.

Something like Digikey # 1091-1026-ND will work.

This is an easy-to-print picture frame to fit Polaroid Originals (and original Polaroid!) pictures. I've included both a single model for larger format printers, and the model split in half for those with smaller printers. Has a slot in the back to insert a US quarter coin as a stand.

Printed in 40% wood PLA.
This thing was made with Tinkercad.

I used to sit my iPad mini in the pull out tray in the center below the dash and use it as a dedicated GPS on long road trips, but I got tired of it sliding around and being so low in my field of view, so I remixed the excellent iPad mini holder by i3Dnaked and adapted it to the change tray just above the radio. It sits just right above the touch screen, and for my height (5'9"), it doesn't block my view of the road. This is my first design, so it's a little blocky, but it's functional. Just remove the rubber tray liner, remove the two screws, drop in the mount, and re-install the two screw so they're snug. My draft print was at 0.3mm height and only 10% infill and it was strong enough to hold the iPad very steady, however I did print out a 0.2mm copy at 50% infill just so I could snug down the screws a little more without worrying about cracking the plastic mount holes. Sliced with Simplify3D using automatic supports. Enjoy!

This is a program, not a thing.  The OpenSCAD file is a template designed to be a good starting point for making Customizer things.  It features MakerBot Replicator Model selection for the purpose of setting build volume, a limiter to restrict your design to the size of your model, and an eraser that does all six cutaway views (or none).  
Warning:  use this for good, not evil.  And do not give it water.
Download the .scad file and keep the original unchanged, copy and rename it to start a new design, and put your design where the comments tell you to put it.  Easy as cake... or Pi...

remixed_from.title: Anet A8 E3D V6 Bowden Dual Extruder Mount Pruisa i3 Clone X Carriage

title: Anet A8 E3D V6 Bowden Dual Extruder Mount Pruisa i3 Clone X Carriage *REAR SENSOR*

description.text:
This is a remix of my own thing, I know...https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2734717

Anyways I made one with a rear sensor setup. The screw holes are sized for 3mm self threading style screws. The instructions below are from the other head. I printed this with supports touching build surface on the sensor mount and all on the rest of it.

I took pictures of the install on my A8. Have a look and let me know what you think!

Here's the timelapse: https://youtu.be/A8XjzGNs6aw

Now, my opinion is that the sensor is too far away with this setup. I like it otherwise though. Looks sweet in brown to green thermal color change. I did design a new variation here:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2766701
This one puts the sensor front and center. It's longest distance from the head is 17mm.

All instructions are for the Anet A8.

This includes guides like my thing https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2732685 built into the mount.

Get the latest Skynet3D firmware from https://github.com/thijsk/Skynet3d and please update your firmware as follows:

Enable RAMPS boards, this is for the common ones like https://goo.gl/XW91zh [Amazon.com link] PLEASE pay attention and be sure to choose the correct code for your motherboards. See boards.h in the Skynet firmware for a list.

define MOTHERBOARD BOARD_RAMPS_14_EEB

Enable dual extruders:

define EXTRUDERS 2

Offsets for the extruders:

define HOTEND_OFFSET_X {0.0, 35.00}
define HOTEND_OFFSET_Y {0.0, 0.00}

For the probe it's :

define X_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER 17.5 // X offset: -left +right [of the nozzle]
define Y_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER 71 // Y offset: -front +behind [the nozzle]
define Z_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER -0.5 // Z offset: -below +above [the nozzle Set this to your machine. I used a .5mm thick print put between the bed and probe with the nozzle touching the bed to start.]

And the travel limits are:

// Travel limits after homing (units are in mm)

define X_MAX_POS 240

define X_MIN_POS -15

define Y_MAX_POS 230

define Y_MIN_POS -13

define Z_MAX_POS 230

define Z_MIN_POS 0

You also must set

// Set the boundaries for probing (where the probe can reach).

define LEFT_PROBE_BED_POSITION 20

define RIGHT_PROBE_BED_POSITION 200

define BACK_PROBE_BED_POSITION 210

define FRONT_PROBE_BED_POSITION 60

I have made a guide in PDF form available here https://goo.gl/1s8jSR for setting the offsets. You will need a serial connection to your printer and I found using Octoprint is really easy.

I am running RAMPS 1.4 with Skynet firmware.

Anyways, this is getting out of hand so here's the important stuff:

Many models to choose from!

  • 18mm sensor
  • 12mm sensor
  • 8mm sensor

Then choose you cap:

  • 2 stock fans with chain mount
  • 2 stock fans no chain mount
  • No fans no chain mount

  • No fans with chain mount

    if you need them there's fan spacers too. I found my duct hit the extruder.

If you go with one with a chain mount I suggest the X axis chain links from https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2193695 This is what I remixed from. You may get the other end mount from here or use mine at https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2762145

Then choose you print settings:

  • Choose .AMF or .STL. I found .AMF more accurate and works in Cura.

  • Made one at .4mm Nozzle, .2mm step, 1.6mm wall and 30% fill worked great

  • Made a second at .4mm nozzle, .2mm step, 1.2mm wall and 15% fill, worked just as good.

    • Do your own of course! You guys know what's what.

You will need:

1) E3D style extruders
2) RAMPS 1.4 or 1.5
3) Marlin/Skynet firmware
4) 40mm M4 Screws and Nuts for the cap, 3 of them
5) 50mm blower fan
6) Wires, connectors, crimpers, and a soldering iron help.

Printer:

Lionized Anet A8 Dual Extruder

Supports:

Yes

Infill:

20%

Notes:

.2mm layer is fine. I run PLA.

title: TronXY X5S simple, reinforced, adjustable X/Y motor mounts

description.text:
Simple X/Y motor mounts, easy to print and easy to install. The motor holes are slotted for adjustment, to help take up any remaining slack after tightening your belts by hand.

These rely on the motors being installed and tightened down for some of their overall rigidity, so don't be alarmed if your prints seem like they might flex a little too much when you're just playing around with them. They'll be rock solid (well, OK... plastic solid) after everything is in place. I highly recommend using washers on the four M3 motor screws. The stock screws have very small heads, and can fairly easily pull through the slots when you're tightening them down. A washer makes everything better.

I printed mine with a 0.2mm layer height and 60% infill, using regular Inland PLA. They have been very sturdy for me, but feel free to use whatever material and settings you think would be best for you.

Inspirational credit for the mounts goes to DracenKnights. These models are very directly based on one of his designs (I'm not sure if they're uploaded here yet), but were modeled from scratch because I needed the CAD practice.

0.2mm

author: morganlowe

description.text:
Work in progress! I designed this little rocket to take the 13mm Estes motors like the 1/2A3-4T. The rocket should go about 400' in the air on a 1/2A3-4T, which will probably put it out of sight. The body tube is sized so the motor will be slightly loose, so please add masking take to your motor for the appropriate friction.

I've included pointy & blunt nose cone models. 20180128: Added versions with square fin tips to give more surface area on the print bed. OpenRocket shows about 1.3 calibers of stability if you print with PETG at 75% infill. 20180129: Added versions with a tube fin and reduced fin length. I don't have any OpenRocket data for this version, so assume it will be extremely dangerous to fly.

The rocket prints as one piece (using supports) and has tumble/featherweight recovery.

I haven't flown this yet, so use at your own risk. OpenRocket says the 6-finned version with semi-rounded tips is about 1.2 to 1.5 calibers stable with any 13mm Estes motor. That stability will depend on the infill you use in the nose cone though. For the first flight, I'm using a 75% infill.

Hello, everyone!!
I finished designing this "Wireless LED Lamp Base"
What does it mean? It means that you can use my three LED lamp and convert them into wireless LED lamp. This is not a difficult project at all. Some parts are difficult to find, so I will provide you the (Ebay) link. Other than that, you are good to go!
In case you want to have top lamp (receiver case) for this wireless lamp base,

  1. Antique Street Lamp
    https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2749960
  2. Round Boroni Lamp
    https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2754475
  3. LED Light Bulb Stand
    https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2755367

Parts you will need...

  1. C1815 Transistor.
  2. 100 or 250 Ohm Potentiometer (Piher Resistor)
    https://www.ebay.com/itm/2-PCS-Piher-Trimmer-Preset-Potentiometer-250-Ohm-PT15V-220-Ohm-V-Mount/220602519421?ssPageName=STRK%3AMEBIDX%3AIT&_trksid=p2060353.m1438.l2649

  3. LED (for the power receiver as tester)

  4. 1K Ohm Resisitor

  5. Enameled copper wire .4 or .5mm dia. about 80-100ft

  6. 3 pin mini slide switch.

  7. Ceramic capacitor 300pF (for the power recevier as tester)

  8. 2.2mm 5V Female Power Jack

  9. 2.2mm 5V USB Power Cable

  10. 75mm cylinder

  11. Soldering Machine

  12. Glue gun

Please, check the diagram I posted. If you have any question, leave a message.
I will gladly help you.
Gook luck and have fun!!!

description.text:
I really like cslang's Razor A5 LUX Carry Bracket but for carrying wasn't comfortable having the weight of the scooter supported by something that simply clips on - I wanted it fastened more securely. My take on this sort of bracket attaches just below the handlebars using two M3x12mm socket head cap screws and nuts and includes a keyed portion on the back to prevent it from twisting once in place. Available to print in two versions - one wider, one narrower as preferred. Both hold the handlebars securely in place when folded and provide an attachment point for a carry strap.

I've installed this on a A5 LUX and on a regular small Razor scooter... The dimensions were the same for both.

title: Fractal Define Mini C fan mount to cool 3.5" hdd (Tempered Glass)

description.text:
Will start off by saying this is designed to fit the Fractal Define Mini C Tempered Glass case, 99% sure it should fit the same chamber dimensions of the normal Define Mini C but am unable to guarantee.

I designed this after noticing recently my 3.5" mechanical hdd reached 43°c (~109°f) with current summer temperatures, after installation of the fan my hdd temp dropped to 33°c (~91°f) at a 27°c (~80°f) ambient temperature.

The fan adapter is designed around measurements of the Noctua NF-R8 redux 80mm, it should work with some other 80mm fans but keep in mind the Noctua actually measures 82mm for the sides by ~26mm deep, and the adapter was spaced at 83mm to allow some room to move, so anything smaller might be a loose fit.

To mount securely you will require a couple of medium zip/cable ties and 4 fan screws. The zip ties go through the side holes and are tied together (see pics) to apply a little pressure to keep the fan held in the mount, but you could instead use double sided tape or hot glue if you have that available. It's a good idea to also be gentle when screwing in the fan mount so as not to overtighten and thread the screw holes.

To actually fit the adapter and fan, you will need to unscrew your PSU, move it backwards as far as you can, unscrew the drive cage and move it far back towards the PSU. The fan and adapter need to slide in diagonally to clear the edge of the case, and once in can be straightened into place and screwed in. The screw holes are a tiny bit off here and there and not perfectly aligned, but close enough. It's easy enough to start the screw and make it fit. Worked first try so wasn't worth a redesign and reprint.

Probably going to get questions about my oddball for a Define Mini C fan size setup here, the PC internals were previously in an Fractal Node 304 ITX case so I'm reusing the Corsair H90 with 2 x 140mm Noctuas in a push pull config, and underneath that is a 120mm fan used as intake for the GPU.

Also, please excuse the horrible print quality in the photo, my printer needs an overhaul!

description.text:
I designed this as a way to prop a couple doors in my house just slightly open due to specific pet needs. This was a much better option than leaving something on the floor between the door and wall and some of the other options out there.

This will work on a door that swings either direction. It will reliably hold the door open from about 2 inches to open at about 80 degrees. The default size is for my doors but could be adjusted by scale to fit other doors. My doors and the model is designed for about 34.5 mm thick. Any doors within a mm or two of that would also probably work without scaling. There is a slight taper to adjust for small variations in size. I used a piece of black "fun foam" to act as a bumper against the door frame.

description.text: This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/jsF6pud6oAz
customized with 3D Slash!

This is a squash-ball foot for making a raised platform for the Ender-2 printer. Print four of these, with ball inserted, and place under a flat base. In the picture I use a kitchen chopping board, approximate dimension 30 cm x 25 cm. You can just use some double-sided tape or glue to attach. The feet are designed so that the large rectangular power supply can be housed under the new platform, and the printer on top. It saves a lot of desk space.

There are three versions - obviously named. One has screw holes for mounting, and the other doesn't - use glue. The third version allows you to test the layout if you don't have a squash ball - there is a printed one already "inserted".

Squash is an actual sport. It's fast and exhausting. Look it up! I played it a lot, in my youth. To complete this build you will need one squash ball per part you print. The foot requires a (preferably) double-yellow dot squash ball to insert into the cup of the foot to provide vibration dampening and noise reduction. You need a ball made for the sport 'squash'. Not a squashy ball, a squishy ball, a squashed ball, or any other type of ball that is not specifically made for the game 'squash'. OK?

I have done some noise measurements using a phone app, printing the same object. Without the platform, I recorded average 45 db, max 51 dB. With the platform, average 41 db, maximum 44 dB. So I'm pretty sure about the noise reduction. I'm still unsure about the vibration aspect and effects on print quality, so this is something you should evaluate yourself.

title: Wobble Fix for Geeetech Prusa I3 X Acrylic

description.text:
The Geeetech Prusa range all seem to have the same wobble issue. I found parts suitable for the metal versions but not the acrylic, so I designed these. The picture shows the wobble clearly, and if you're not convinced, see this video of the wobble!

I have two versions and one uses less filament than the other, but the other (I think) looks nicer. The two STL files are not the exact version I have printed as I have modified them slightly further so they avoid a few of the screws (which mine rub up against)

The first printed layer contains a small rectangle over where the rod would come through. You need to remove this after the print, it is there to help that section remain stuck to the base while printing

If you want to see how (badly) I made them, they're both on Tinkercad as:
Normal Version on TinkerCad
Smaller Version on TinkerCad

Hope you enjoy better print quality!

Future I might mod this to make it thinner as once the screws are tightened there's quite a bit of wasted height and it only just fits the printer. Still, the links are above so you can do this yourself!

The very first layer there is a small rectangle added that you need to remove. This helps it stick to the base! - Printed on the Geeetech Prusa I3 X Acrylic

Learn Tinkercad

comments.text:
This certainly prints and works well enough, but if your print bed is less that 200mm (as my XYZPrinting da Vinci 2.0 Duo is) then you have to print it standing upright and as a result you lose an enormous volume of plastic for the supports for all 3 pieces at once is enormous. With thick shells, 1mm layers, and solid infill it cost me 0.782KG of PLA.
I strongly recommend that you use ABS on a 200mm x 200mm print bed for printing this as the marble support center falls apart in PLA and the top and bottom as well as the Mable holder require 6 times the plastic of the 3 items just for supports. It's great, but print each piece laying flat and print each of the 3 parts individually or accept losing most of your 1KG plastic spool for the required supports alone.

description.text:
You can change the clearance in the joint by changing the values of the variable "s" (in the BlocksCAD file (https://www.blockscad3d.com/editor)) and printing the test model to know what value "s" to use.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=gtVZzjpj9WY
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6vrzy89dJOM

0.1 - 0.2

100%

Notes:

It is important to set a good level of the printing plate so that the details does not print with the influx, and does not fall off.

The most difficult part is to separate the detail from the printing plate and bring the hinges into working mode because this thing is not monolithic and contains 60 separate elements and 90 joints.

When I separated the snowflake from the printing plate, I broke one of the rays.
Instead of printing a new one, I printed one beam and attached it to the main part with the help of heat.

After you bring the hinges into working condition, it is recommended to lightly oil them with silicone oil.

title: Mitchie Whoop - No supports tiny whoop frame 5g

description.text:
A tiny whoop frame i designed to print without supports. Ive been printing it in PLA, at 0.3mm it weighs 4.96grams. Many of the walls on the top part are only 2 layers thick to reduce weight (on 0.4mm nozzle). The screw holes are way oversized at 1.4mm but that makes them print correctly on my FDM printer, if youre using something more accurate than what ive got the screw holes may be too big, you can just hit em with a lighter and squeeze em to be tighter. you can maybe also melt/solder(3d pen) the 2 frame pieces together. i notice they pop apart in crashes sometimes.

I wanted to take a stab a whoop frame that doesn't suck and is easy to print, this is the result. I think i may have gone as far as i can with this design but i have some thoughts on other designs. If you break one comment where it broke, maybe i can make a more durable v2 if there are some weak spots. Also please post a make photo if you make one, i love to see that.

description.text: Replacement accessories for the Luna Girl figure which comprises a Hoverboard and a bow-shaped weapon.
Broke my frame so i made a new one.

Handheld linux game console based on the PocketBeagle and other small PCBs

I'm still investigating suitable audio modules and speakers, but have a phatDAC currently installed in my test unit.

The buttons may take some finishing to for fit & comfort. I glued the button faces to the tact buttons, installed them in the case, then glued the button backing pieces to the buttons, and then soldered the wires to the buttons. The legs of all the buttons except the start & select buttons have been splayed flat. The start & select button legs are folded under, wires soldered in place, and the buttons glued in place. A future version will likely add alignment tabs to the backing plates to make assembly easier.

I used the simple gaming cape as a starting point for the design, and most of the GPIO usage is the same, with the addition of two buttons and an I2S dac.

Parts list
  • PocketBeagle here
  • adafruit ILI9340 2.2" TFT here
  • a suitably large microSD card for the OS & Games.
  • OPTIONAL: RTL8188CUS micro dongle for WiFi, disassemble and solder to USB1 pins.
  • OPTIONAL: phatDAC for sound output (may change in the future)
  • 10 long-stem (4MM) tactile buttons
  • one micro SPST switch for switching power on & off.
  • micro usb male & female breakouts (to extend USB0 from the pocket to the case)
  • one lipo battery

print_settings.Notes:: I usually print several at a time so I have spares for other wire sizes or breakage.
print_settings.Printer:: Wanhao Duplicator i3 Plus

description.text: The toroid bobbin makes winding toroidal inductors and transformers relatively easy by holding at least 1m (T37-size) of enameled copper wire. The bobbin also provides a grip for tightening the wire to the toroidal form.

Printer Brand:

Wanhao

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3 Plus

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1mm

Notes:

Built with PETG. Probably OK with ABS. PLA might be too brittle.

PETG print: bed: 55-60C, Extruder: 225C

Supports may be needed for sizes larger than T37-size because tips curve up slightly.

I usually print several at a time so I have spares for other wire sizes or breakage.
T37-size holds at least 1m of #28 AWG (.35mm) and may be a bit snug in a 1-layer T37 toroid, but will push through. Edges might need to be smoothed a bit.

I was building several radio kits with 20+ toroid inductors and transformers. I wound several toroids using a long length of enameled wire and counted and recounted turns. How frustrating! I remembered some techs 40+ years ago talking about winding toroids using a bobbin. I could not find such a gadget in this century via an Internet search. I tried making a bobbin using some heavy duty business card stock, but it bent and frayed quickly. I cut a scrap of PLA raft material, but the points broke and the thin wire jammed in the V-notch. So I 3D-printed my own design. It has worked very well for both T37- and T50-sized toroids.

Bobbins for larger toroids can be scaled up from the T37-size using a slicer. The image shows a bobbin 3.5x larger with a T130 core and two T37 bobbins with a LPF circuit with 3 T37 inductors.

My method for counting turns is to wind five turns, then mark the fifth turn with a very fine point marker (while relaxing my arthritic hands). (I guess what the spacing between turns should be, and will adjust when finished.) Then wind another 5 turns, and another mark. Repeat until all turns are on. I don't mark the last few turns. (Remember that each time the wire passes through the hole is one turn.)

I then adjust the turn spacing after all the turns are on so they are even, while leaving about a 30 degree gap between the starting turn and the final turn. It's very easy to count that the toroid has 27 turns on it.

description.text:
This is my pod for the Karearea Talon.
It is designed around the following components and is a tight fit.
Camera: Runcam Micro Swift http://bit.ly/2FWbfDP
RX: XSR http://bit.ly/2FXHq5K
VTX: Unify HV Race
VTX Antenna: AXII ufl
FC: Flip32 F4 http://bit.ly/2Du5IWB
ESC: 4in1 30a 2-5s http://bit.ly/2G0EG7W

The fins act as camera protection and house all antennas. There are 2 tubes for the rx antennas and then the AXII fits in the bulge at the back. To attach the pod to the frame you will need some M3 nuts and bolts.
V3 adds more camera protection and a bit more room in the pod. It also adds a 45' 4 LED mount on the back (should be the perfect angle for people to see your LEDs when behind you).
V4 goes back to the V2 shape, with added horns for camera protection. It also swaps out the normal hexagon M3 nuts for square ones (http://bit.ly/2rV463U). The hole for the AXII has been moved out a bit, this exposes it slightly but gives it a much tighter mount. A 45' LED mount for a 4 LED board has been added to the rear. Lastly the antenna holes are now triangular to allow them to print well without supports.

WARNING: The Karearea Talon is not designed to be used without it's carbon fiber pod. By running this pod you increase the chances of damaging the aluminium parts of the frame in a crash. Use at your own risk.

A lot of time and effort went in to designing this pod, so if you enjoy using it please consider clicking the Tip Designer button :)

Printer:

CR 10 Mini

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Infill:

30%

Notes:

Print in TPU, I recommend SainSmart TPU for it's stiffness http://amzn.to/2mWCSVr .
Set walls to 1.4mm so the main walls are solid.

description.text: This is a kitchen magnetic knife holder using some 60 x 10 x 5 mm magnets I had laying around the house. We had all these extra knifes and the kids and I kept cutting ourselves when they were in the drawer. Sure, I could have ordered one from amazon, but where is the fun in that. I printed this in PETG, but you can use anything realistically. I used epoxy glue to hold the magnets in the sockets. The one pictured is actually quite a bit thicker, but I remolded it to about half that thickness since I felt it was overdone and saves on material. I included 2 versions, the full versions for those with large print beds and a 2 part version for smaller print beds that can be glued together. I found the magnets on amazon :https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B072K5SLXK/ref=oh_aui_search_detailpage?ie=UTF8&psc=1, listed as Rare-Earth Metal Neodymium Magnet, N45, Incredibly Strong 33+ LB Strength - 60 x 10 x 5 mm

description.text:
This remake uses the OLED World Clock box by Ken3d to create a interesting clock that will appeal to those who grew up on those retro games. It includes Pong, Pacman and Tetris.

Acknowledgements

OLED World Clock box by Ken3d (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1494309)
Pong Clock code by 0miker0 & mic159
Wunderground code by Daniel Eichhorn

Build

STL files are at https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1494309
The clock has a custom PC board used to hold a ESP-01 board. It contains a 3V3 regulator, headers for a 0.96" I2C OLED display as well as a header and pullup resistors for the two buttons. The ESP-01 board has 4 IO pins, two of which are normally RX and TX. These have been repurposed for the two buttons. The other two IO pins are used for the I2C bus (SDA and SCL). I made my board using the toner method. (Eagle files included).

Programming the ESP-01 can be a bit challenging. You need to hold GPIO0 pin low to while you program it. The Internet contains a number of sites that describe the process. The Sketch and associated libraries are included.

Operation

The code is basically taken from the Pong Clock by 0miker0 & mic159 (https://github.com/mike-rankin/Pong-Clock/blob/master/Code/README.md). All I did was remove the Real Time Clock (RTC) code and replace it with a NTP Client (Network Time Server). This means it still has all the code to change the date and time. However, no matter what you change it to, the clock will always obtain the time from the NTP server.

When started, the WiFi Manager will try and connect to your WiFi network. If it can't be found or this is the first time you are running the software, it will create a WiFi hotspot called CLOCK. Using your phone, connect to this WiFi hotspot. You will be presented with a menu. You can either select your network SID from the list or enter one manually. You will be asked for the password if it is required.

Once connected, it will then get your latitude and longitude and using this location, connect to the WUnderground service. This service will return your time-zone, taking into account daylight savings time. The software then contacts a NTP server to get the current time using the time-zone obtained previously.

One button switches between the different games while the other brings up a menu.

title: Gopro Remote Control Mount for El Grande Extension Pole

description.text:
Warning: This mod will void the warranty of your remote control! I'm not responsible for any damages.

Since I didn't want to carry around another charging cable, I've added a micro usb breakout board (e.g. https://blog.adafruit.com/2014/04/18/new-product-usb-micro-b-breakout-board/).
No soldering was necessary, the charging pins will fit directly to the board.
You will also need 2 X M2.5 10mm bolts and nuts.

Instructions:

  • Remove the 4 screws on the back of your remote control.
  • Mount the breakout board on the top part.
  • Plug in a USB cable and check if the remote is charging. You might have to bend the pins or to solder a cable in case you have another breakout that does not match.
  • Screw the remote control on the top part. Don't overwind!
  • Screw the top part on the lower part.
  • Have fun!

title: Sparkcube XL E3D V6 Cooling-Assembly + Mount + Part Cooler

description.text:
I had make a re-design of the parts.
This parts are designed for a friend with a E3D V6 Full Metall in a Sparkcube XL (2017 Design). He had has problems with the original Sparkcube XL cooling Fan design and to low cooling effect.

I made a fast re-design without detail finishing. (Some corner and edges look`s a little bit sharp) but it works. "If i had time, i make a design with 4 mounting screws for the partscooler." I had design it and uploaded under V2. This design has lager bores for M3 and the Partcooler sit 2 mm deeper. Is not tested.

The Hotendcooler/Mount is a re-design of Skimmy`s Parts an the Parts-cooler is a re-design of Middleman Part.

The Pictures are all from my friend and i update it later for better detail pictures.

You need small amount of support but i found no way for a support-free design.

ATTENTION! The Heatblock of the hotend had to be protected with captontape or Silicone completely to save the printed Parts and prevent fire.

The Parts are modular.
First combination:
Fan-Carrierclamp
Fan 30x30x10mm (Delievered cooling fan at the most e3D V6 and klones)
Airduct Part A (Airduct Parts are interchangeable, Part A for screw and B for Nut)
Airduct Part B
Airoutlet
Partcooler

Second combination:
Bigger Fan (if you need it)
Fan adapter (example: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:21112 )
Fan-Carrierclamp
Fandummy 30x30x10
Airduct Part A (Airduct Parts are interchangeable, Part A for screw and B for Nut)
Airduct Part B
Airoutlet

The system is designed to work with the redesigned mount for the Hotend.
All screw`s for mountig to the Fanduct are M3, screws to connect the Fanducts together are M4.

Steps:
-If you had an thread cutter M3 cut all bores in the parts (look for the deep of the bores), all bores you see. If you didnt had a thread cutter screw a M3 screw carefully one time into the holes

  • Assemble the E3D V6 into the mount (Ring of the mount to top) and screw in 1 or 2 short M3 into the bore to fix it (not to strong). It is designed for a strong fit. Grind it for a perfekt fit.
  • Mount it to your carrier
  • Assemble all needed Parts to the Fanduct`s
  • Glue or press the M4 Nut into the Fanduct Part B
  • Assemble the Fanducts from the side`s onto the hotendcooler and carrier and screw it together with M4
  • Assemble the Partcooling Fan to the Partcooler
  • Screw the Partcooler to the Fanduct

description.text:
Be aware that I adapted the inner diameter of the "hole" for the motion sensor to have it come out the proper size on my printer.

I recommend printing a few layers and then check if your sensor fits into the opening at the base of the holder. If not, simply adjust the size of the holder in your slicer and try again. But don´t be to generous with enlarging, it has to be a tight fit or the sensor will fall out.

For horizontal installation at the ceiling the sensor stays in place by gravity alone but if you use it vertically it might be a good idea to simply stuff some tissue paper behind it (doesn´t hurt for horizontal installation either) to keep it in place.

description.text: T-nuts for 3030 profile. You have to drill the hole for bolt (it print better this way)

After having lost my charger cable and finding out that the original replacement part was rather expensive, I decided to print the adaptor myself. Just drill two 1mm holes into the part and stick two small nails wires through and solder them to an old USB printer cable and off your go!
In order to improve the contact beween the nails and my garmin device I added three turns of a small spring (probably from an old 3.5" floppy disk).
In the pictures you see mk1 which is a bit short. MkII is slightly longer to make it easier to attach the rubber band. description.text:
Halter für 2. Display an der DJI Phantom / Inspire Fernbedienung
Manchmal ist es sinnvoll, zusätzlich zum Tablet noch ein 2. Display an der Fernbedienung einer DJI Phantom oder Inspire zu haben. Zum Beispiel zum Abrufen von externen Daten, wie Wetter, Flugverkehr oder "No Fly Zones".
Der Halter wird einfach über den Tablethalter an der Fernbedienung geschoben und hat eine GoPro-Kompatible Befestigung für einen Handyhalter. Der hier abgebildete Handyhalter ist für ein iPhone 6s. Halter mit GoPro-Befestigung für andere Handys findet ihr auf Thingiverse.

Holder for 2nd display on the DJI Phantom / Inspire remote control
Sometimes it makes sense to have a second display on the remote control of a DJI Phantom or Inspire in addition to the tablet. For example, to retrieve external data such as weather, air traffic or "no fly zones".
The holder is simply slid over the tablet holder on the remote and has a GoPro-compatible mount for a mobile phone holder. The phone holder shown here is for an iPhone 6s. Holders with GoPro mount for other phones can be found on Thingiverse.

title: Credit Card / Loyalty Card Holder / Wallet

description.text:
If you enjoy any of my Things, please sponsor my charity cycle ride to Paris. https://www.justgiving.com/fundraising/petethevanstp or text PTVC63 £5 to 70070 (UK number). Expires 1st May 2018. Thanks!

Are you fed up with those loyalty cards falling out in your pocket or handbag and getting lost? I was, so I designed a holder for up to three loyalty cards. The trick was to get them thin enough to fit but thick enough for strength. They will just fit into a credit card slot (if you're lucky :-))

I used PLA, but ABS/PETG would probably be a better bet so you can get the strength.

There are two sets of STL's - front & back and an all-in-one version. Your choice. One of the pictures shows the "one piece" after printing vertically using a 10mm brim. This one happens to be in transparent black PETG.

The two halves are not the same - one is flat, the other has 0.6mm sides that form a box with the top.

After printing, remove from the bed and glue using Super Glue (or your favourite). EDIT: Superglue didn't cut it for me, the parts kept separating after a while. I had more success with Araldite. Out of curiosity, I tried to make it in one piece and it works - "Loyalty Card Holder One Piece.stl". Print vertically with no supports, just a 10mm brim.

You can print the two halves together if you like.

Note: Thingiverse shows them vertical, I printed them flat (make sure the tiny sides are uppermost), but I can't see why you shouldn't try them this way. If you do, you'll need a hefty raft/brim to hold them steady.

Printer:

Geeetech Aluminium

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

As fine as possible - 0.1 or better.

Infill:

Absolutely 100%

Notes:

There's no need for any raft or supports.

Glue & clean-up.

Glue carefully along all edges, paying particular attention to the corners.

For the one-piece version, just clean up the print using a file etc. if required.

Fusion 360 / CURA

Very simple to design using Fusion 360. The trick was to get the gap right so that the cards would have a slight interference fit. I managed to get it right first time - I guess the tolerances may change depending upon your printer.

title: Little Bird MH-6 for 250 size RC Heli

description.text:
Littlebird helicopter from Battle Field 2 ,as with the previous Airwolf model a mix of Sketchup , Netfabb and blender were used to make this model printable, this has already been printed and i will upload photos once it is trimmed/sanded etc.
Its a slightly bigger model that the Airwolf despite being for the same size electronics this is mostly just due to the helicopters overall shape it does however end up being approx the same weight.
The front cockpit i printed with 2 perimeters 2 top and 1 bottom layer, i printed it with skirt and generated supports using Simplify, you end up removing maybe 60% of the print as its mostly support material.
The body was printed tail end first , mostly to reduce the need to print the supports ( if you print it wide end first it will generate supports to hold the middle wall which you will end up removing to fit the electronics) i used 2 perimeters with 0 top and bottom layers at 0.25mm layer height and it came out perfectly.
The boom i printed with only 1 perimeter and 0 top and 0 bottom layers , the boom is in two pieces and you can just glue them together or use tape which ever you prefer.
The machine guns and rocket pods i printed at 0.25mm layer height choose your walls etc to suit your required level of detail , they are located pretty centrally so weight distribution isnt so much of an issue.
Main rotor head and blades are for static display only ( obviously ) if you try to fly with them , well , you wont get very far.
i did not print skids but i have included them.

Windows will be next.

title: Book shelf pin hole jig drill alignment tool

description.text:
there are many store bought shelf pin jigs available but most of them are expensive so I simple designed one myself.

Typical shell pins are 5mm in diameter but the jig has 9.6mm holes. This is because it needs to be used not with a 5mm drill but with a self centering drill. The self centering drill I bought has a 9,6mm outer diameter and a 5mm drill. Using this I won' t damage my jig while drilling.

I bought this one from aliexpress:
https://www.aliexpress.com/item/NEW-2-Sizes-HSS-Brass-Self-Centering-Hinge-Twist-Drill-Bits-1-4-5mm-Screw-Hole/32798182907.html?spm=a2g0s.9042311.0.0.iWCz5n

The Chiss Star Destroyer was a kilometer-long capital ship used by the military of the Chiss Ascendancy, first observed during their conflict with the Killik Colony in 35 ABY.

The Chiss Star Destroyer somewhat resembled the 900m Victory-class Star Destroyer design still being used by the Galactic Federation of Free Alliances, but its gray hull was slightly longer and slimmer, giving it an aggressive, needle-shaped appearance.

Like most Star Destroyer designs, the Chiss capital ships were powerful, but were also vulnerable to a concerted starfighter assault. Their precise capabilities are unknown, but the ships of the class were outfitted with Chiss versions of the range of equipment found aboard a typical Star Destroyer.

Primary armament consisted of beam weapons, including both light and heavy mountings, and divided between conventional turbolasers and the distinctive Chiss energy/particle megamasers. The ships were outfitted with tractor beams projectors, ray shields, and particle shields, the last of which were capable of stopping a few kamikaze dartships but not an entire swarm on a suicide run.

title: Schlage 5-pin KIK adapter for Sargent and Greenleaf padlocks

description.text:
This is an adapter that will allow you to use standard Schlage 5-pin KIK cylinders inside Sargent and Greenleaf 826/831/833 locks. It's common for people to acquire these locks without keys or even a medeco KIK cylinder. Since these lost are usually US Military restricted and getting replacement keys/cylinders are out of the question, they are left with a large paperweight.

This will allow you to at least put it into service. Here's a video of it in action with a 5-pin Schlage KIK (no pins in it since I didn't have a key for it) https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=O6vsxahiwbY&feature=youtu.be

Could not find any quick and easy to print Lithophane boxes so I have attempted to design this to hold four 90x90x3mm Lithophanes and have easy mounting of the popular and easy to find usb remote controlled rgb light strips used for televisions approx. 900mm long.

I print my lithophanes vertically with 3mm border and base and plenty of brim to keep print stuck to bed. I use http://3dp.rocks/lithophane/ to create the lithophanes with settings as uploaded. I sometimes use a little curvature setting from 5 to 15 to help the lithophane stability while printing and you can see om my printed model some have curvature.

The main box structure should be able to print with no support, but would only appear on cabling hole.
The tube is 0.5mm thick so is designed to print in spiral mode, and I recommend with a brim which can stay attached.
The top should be printed up side down.

Assembly is fairly simple.
Wrap led strip around tube and use a little wire or similar with holes to keep in place.
Feed usb cable through hole.
Put cross shaped piece into main structure into lugs.
Slip tube over circular section of cross shaped piece.
Insert Lithophanes into slots in main structure.
Put top piece over everything ensuring each corner of main structure has inserted into top piece.
Connect to suitable usb source which should be 1 amp or more, turn on and enjoy.

This is the 3d printed version of the tiny whoov (V4 already).

for those who have already printed the v1, v2 or v3 > On v4 I reduced frame global size and wall thickness to minimize the weight (only 16grams now!!!) and made cam holder & battery hatch separatly in case you don't need them or want to replace them. Upon, request I've also separated the skirt from the main body so that you don't need to print support and can print it in another frictionless material

For the others : It's a micro rc hovercraft based on microquads electronics (check scratchbuild version to know more).

Still super easy : you need to print and glue 4 parts :

  • main body
  • skirt
  • the battery hatch (optional)
  • the cam holder (optional)

general infos about tinywhoov :

https://youtu.be/-kZM0Icg0BY
https://youtu.be/6sUAy4ytuQw

FEW OTHER TIPS FOR THE BUILD :

1) PRINT THE MAIN BODY AND THE SKIRT HORIZONTALLY and THE FINS VERTICALLY (it will look much better).

2) get the right positioning for the motors !!
BACK MOTORS OF THE QUAD = THRUST AND DIRECTION
FRONT MOTORS OF THE QUAD = LIFT (hover)

2bis) if you use inductrix/whoop propellers > they work much better when blowing air towards the motors (like they do on the micro quad). If you reverse, you will loose efficiency.

3) try to keep it as light as possible (under 50-40gr for best performances).

4) You can add a "skirt" made of a plastic bag to make it even better, but it works very well without it.

Please note that this 3d printed version is a bit heavier than the foam one (featured in my first video). It' works very well but if you want best performances you should make it in foam (check my other things for all infos and drawings).

Feedbacks appreciated ! And if you really love it, share it and/or leave me a tip, that will help me going with this project ;)

Darrel Imhoff : thanks for your help and the pictures

Enjoy !

comments.text: I built one up using the V4 model and the hardware from an Inductrix FPV. The transmitter setup worked perfectly with the original inductrix, but in the Whoov, it spins one way or the other when power is applied. Also, the rudder control had to be reversed from the original quad setup to get it to turn the right way. Once it starts spinning, it accelerates and cannot be stopped with rudder control (either direction). Acts like the stabilization in the quad board is not compatible, or backwards. I tried "stabilize" mode and "agility" mode, and in both cases it does the same thing. Just holding the unit in your hand and powering up a bit, when you rotate it CW or CCW, you can hear the motors speed up/spin down with no stick input other than raising the throttle to get the props spinning, The motors and board are in the same orientation as in the quad. Thoughts? [email protected]
comments.author: kenjochim

print_settings.Notes:: For the Benchy, this I printed without supports.  The Voxels are smaller on this example so they are more like overhangs.  This seemed to work well but there were a couple places where supports would have been helpful like back of the roof near the smokestack.

description.text:
Voxelize is an OpenSCAD module that you can use to create voxel art out of other models.

To use you'll want to find the minimum and maximum point that is the corners of a box that would contain your model. Pass these points to the voxelize function as p0 and p1. pass in a step (i.e. voxel size) and an optional overlap (important for making it printable). The procedure will take several minutes depending on the steps and complexity of the model. You may get a few warnings during processing; this is normal. Excessive warnings can mean your volume is much larger than it needs to be. If you are getting errors, it is possible that your model is too complex to be processed. Try reducing the complexity of your model with MeshMixer or your favorite capable app.

There are two examples included.
Credit for Original 3DBenchy model: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:763622
Credit for Stanford Bunny Model: From MeshMixer.

Tips:

  • Use overlap of about 0.2 to be sure models are solid setting overlap to zero could mean voxels touching only by edges or corners.
  • Expect the voxelize function to take a long time. The included bunny included examples can take 15 to 20 minuets or more to process.
  • Reduce complexity of models beforehand to reduce processing time improve success. E.g. the Benchy example was reduced by 95% in MeshMixer so it could successfully be processed by voxelize.
  • Offset the starting point, p0, by -1/2 step after finding the minimum for your model. This will improve symmetry since samples are taken at step boundries.

Have fun! Don't forget to post your creations and let me know if you have any questions or suggestions.

More to come!

~ QuantumZ

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.25mm

Infill:

10% - 20%

Notes:

For the bunny, I printed this by rotating it 45 degrees towards his back then add supports manually. This made the supports easier to remove and gave the voxels a more rounded appearance.

For the Benchy, this I printed without supports. The Voxels are smaller on this example so they are more like overhangs. This seemed to work well but there were a couple places where supports would have been helpful like back of the roof near the smokestack.

print_settings.Notes:: Printed in PLA with  3 outer shells.

description.text: My niece wanted a big bolt and nut with some weight to it. This bolt was big, but light, so I filled it with a pound of black iron oxide. Now it has a nice heft to it that surprises everyone who picks it up.

Printer Brand:

Printrbot

Printer:

Printrbot Plus

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

15%

Notes:

Printed in PLA with 3 outer shells.

Adding weight to a plastic bolt

I printed this and stopped the print at the last 3 mm and removed it from the printer. I then poured a pound of black iron oxide down the center to fill the void. Using Magic-Sculpt two part epoxy putty I closed off the end and filed and sanded it smooth. A coat of primer then two coats of Valspar Metallic Silver paint finished it.

I also modeled a washer to fit the bolt just to further sell it as a real bolt.

Sand would probably work too, but the iron oxide seemed to pack better, and provided a little more weight.

I put a light coat of Pledge spray wax on the threads. A light spin of the nut now sends it all the way down the bolt and slams it up against the washer.

title: Ultimate Jig Saw Handle
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Ultimate Jig Saw Handle

Two days ago I printed this model https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2491385, and i got some problems :

  • The hole for the blade is too big for Bosh blades.
  • The container cap is too weak, i've lost it.
  • The tightening ring fits to my fingers but due to missing blocking system i think it would not be secured all along the manipulation. Not really reliable
  • the handle is split, so post print is required

So, ...after a few hours of fusion360 and some test prints, i've done

  • All parts are new designs, no split parts for handle.
  • Fits perfectly to Bosch blades
  • Screw cap to avoid to loose blades
  • The container accepts more than 8 blades
  • Secured manipulation with screwed tightening ring

All parts are fully printable. The handle has smooth overhangs (no-bridge) and fits perfectly to hand.

description.text:
A very simple hinged treasure chest that is printed in two pieces.  The hinged pieces snap into place very nicely and the hinge is snug enough that the lid can remain partially open without falling closed/open.  Images show chest printed at layer thickness of .27mm, so it would be even cleaner at a lower setting.
Chest can be printed with NO RAFT SUPPORT.  The image shown here is without any raft support on either piece.
Lid and base printed separately.

The .s3g files are the ready-for-print versions of the chest with 10% infill, 0 shells, .27mm layer height, and feedrate of 40.  If you'd prefer to adjust the scale and settings, grab the .stl files instead and export your own gcode.
Print lid and base and then snap the hinge together.  Very simple and straightforward.

This was an accidental feature due to lack of foresight that I liked and went with.

description.text:
This small toy was my first attempt to design in FreeCAD a composed object.

You should print (and clean and polish, sorry) 19 pieces that were designed to fit togheter but usually don't when printed with my printer. Hope yours will do better. Anyway, with some sand paper, assembly problems should be solved.

Please notice that the "bike.stl" file was uploaded to show the bycicle fully assembled, but it is not printable.

In the version I'm uploading I increased the gaps between parts to be mounted together to decrease the post pocessing work. Let me know if it is too much for you.

Assembly is quite stright forward. Some exploded design uploaded to better explain usage of small parts.

I added a retention ring to be glued on the fork shaft not shown in the pics but included in the files.

Some good cyanoacrylate recommended. I used standard one only for wheel halves, for the rest better if you use gel.

20th piece is a small elastic band, see below for instructions.

Printer:

Anycubic I3 Ultrabase

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0,2mm

Infill:

30%

Notes:

Important: some pieces must be rotated before printing to make they lay down the printer bed: frame, fork, stand.

Printed with Anycubic black PLA @205° bed @65°
Platform adhesion type: brim (10 lines) needed for small parts and parts printed with support.
Supports needed for frame, saddle, stem, crank arms.
For supports I used "lines", 15% fill amount, 0.7mm X/Y distance, 0.15mm Z distance, overhang 30° (maybe not the best but somehow working for me).

Lot of post-printing work needed sorry

Because of the supports, a lot of patience is needed to clean up the pieces after printing.
Also sanding is needed for parts that were designed to fit together but will not after printed :-)
A good set of small files or rasps is recommended.
Some good drill bits (used by hand on PLA!) also will help in rectifying holes.

Last: the chain is an elastic band stolen on my wife's desk. Unfortunately even if the right size, it can't be mounted as it is because of the frame printed in one piece. Solution: cut diagonally the band, insert it in the frame, and glue with a good cyanoacrylate gel. Double check the position before glueing!

Somewhat of a one trick pony but I was having difficulty inserting the micro SD into the Raspberry Pi 3 after you have connected a 7 inch touch display.
The notch on this small tool allows you to slide it onto the SD card and remove it much easier than trying to get your fingers in there, without damaging it.
It also makes it much easier to handle the SD and insert it into the pi.
Printing it in high resolution seems to work much better.
If you need to make it longer, you should be able to simply adjust that length without affecting it's ability to grab the micro SD.
Printing in black PLA also seemed to work better than the maroon PET in the image.

Hope it helps others with not so nimble fingers. :)

title: MakerFarm Prusa i3v Z Axis Couplers

description.text:
MakerFarm Prusa i3v Z Axis Couplers. Dimensioned .022" over to allow for material shrinkage. The stepper side of the coupler fits nicely onto the stepper shaft with minimal interference. Clean up the lead screw side I.D. with a .187" drill. Very little material will be removed. It will thread straight onto the lead screw. Make sure to clean up coupler mating surfaces so both sides fit together to your liking. This should be minimal as well.

Use version 2 if you would like the couplers to snap together easier. Also resized the lead screw side I.D. so that there is no need to use a drill bit to clean out. Stepper side shaft fitting is a little tighter.

Added ZAxisCouplers_Short in case X axis rail clearance is an issue or if you simply would like smaller couplers.

title: Anet A8 mainboard cover with reset button

description.text:
I ideally wanted a quick and easy cover for the mainboard, but all the cases seemed like overkill and took too long to print (10 hrs anyone!?).

When I saw thankHUWverymuch's original model and ingenious spiral button (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2078881), I thought it would be great to incorporate it into a simple flat cover. I also took inspiration from Lee-R's cover (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2013479), but didn't use the model or his measurements.

It fits with about 23mm clearance under the cover to the board, plenty for airflow but not enough to hide all the wires comfortably and safely. I just tied mine to the side in a little bundle (see pic).

Future updates could include more clearance and a side extension to secure and hide the extra wires.

remixed_from.author: BoldPrintShop
remixed_from.title: LARGE Destiny Ghost Fully Detailed Model, LED Illuminated, no supports!

title: Large Destiny Ghost Remixed Parts
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I printed a Ghost for a friend's birthday but ended up remixing various parts:

  • The Destiny logo is now separate from the stand so you can print it in 2 colours. There are locating pins to help align the parts.
  • The lens now has a half sphere on the rear to properly diffuse the light from the LED.
  • The front and rear bodies are adapted to hold together with magnets.
  • The front body and rear dial are adapted for 8 petal LED tealights.
  • The horn has been re-oriented to print flat on the bed.

Someone else had remixed the bodies and dial for 8 petal tea lights and magnets, but the STLs were broken and had been remeshed to a much lower resolution, so I decided to re-make these based on the originals. (When importing existing STLs into TinkerCad, it seems to help if you import them at 1000% scale, then scale them back down after import. This preserves a lot more detail when TinkerCad remeshes the model. Microsoft 3D Builder is also really good at fixing up STLs exported from TinkerCad.)

You'll need 6mmx1mm magnets for the body halves, as well as the eye, wing and wing insert parts from the original large Ghost model (see "remixed from" on the right).

Thanks to the original model authors, and I hope you find these useful! :)

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

i3 MK2S

Rafts:

No

Notes:

That stand is fine at 0.2mm resolution, but print the logo as high as you can - I used 0.05mm. Everything else was printed at 0.15mm. Supports were used inside the body and dial.

author: jbrum360

print_settings.Notes:: [Advanced]

description.text:
This is a highly customizable, fully printable bearing. It can be printed with a fairly low end printer (I use Anet A8) and still work because it can be cleaned up before assembling. It also doesn't require any supports and likely no raft/brims.

Obviously it doesn't spin as well as a bearing made of metal, but I think it is still good enough for light applications. Here is a video to see how well it spins: https://youtu.be/E3SVvrHNiLI

I haven't tested many parameter combinations (there are millions), but I've chosen default settings that seem to work pretty well. For other parameters take a look at the 'section' view to make sure things look ok before printing.

The latest version I've uploaded fixes some minor tolerance issues, and gives better default values for the customizer.

Printer:

Anet A8

Resolution:

0.2

Notes:

Print all parts separately. Don't forget to print enough rollers and two retainers.

I've had a bit better results by using a 'One at a Time' print sequence. This can reduce retraction artifacts.

These are the current default parameters. The STL files were generated using these values:

// Outer radius
outerRadius = 18; //[14:0.5:50]
// Inner radius
innerRadius = 6; //[3.5:0.5:45]
// Width
width = 13; //[10:0.5:50]
// Tolerance (extra space between rollers and races)
tolerance = 0.2; //[0.05:0.05:0.5]
// Number of rollers
numRollers = 7; //[3:50]

/ [Advanced] /
// Thickness of walls (should be a multiple of your nozzle diameter)
wallThickness = 0.8; //[0.1:0.1:5]
raceLipWidth = 2;
rollerHoleRadius = 2;
retainerBaseHeight = 0.6; //[0.2:0.1:1]

5 Rollers

No additional materials required for assembly, it snaps together. I found it easiest to put the inner, outer and one retainer in place, then slide each roller through the slot, then put the final retainer on. Cleanup and assembly have taken me about 15 min.

7 Rollers

author: yemen7

description.text: Acehe 1500mah 95c protection

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

i3 MK2S

Resolution:

0,2

This model is to represent the "defrocked" M-7 priest SPGs; used by allied forces in late 1944 and early 1945, by removing the main gun from these vehicles and adding steel plate to provide protection to the infantry. These were the first true fully tracked APCs.
I started with the M7 in 1/100th scale from https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1037138. Thansk to manifold destiny for his contribution.
I upsized it to 1/56th (28mm); removed the crew, ammo racks and the like; redrafted the MG "pulpit" so it would be to proper scale. I added the steel plates and bolts etc. on Tinkercad.

Just like original.
Only changes were I made a single, 4 hole, 6 hole and 7 hole racks.

comments.author: wirlybird

comments.text: Mirror mounting foam tape is the way to go in that case. But be sure to buy a good one, since those unbranded ones have a tendency to loose adhesion over time.
comments.author: wirlybird

comments.text:
I have gone with Gorilla tape, it was fairly wide so I thought extra hold. I ended up making a "bar that goes behind the holders to join them together. I needed a "4" and a "3' for my door!
My cabinet doors are the standard raised panel type and the panel is thin so no screws!
What I made is a flat "bar" that is about the same height as the flat part of the back of the holder. It is the width of the inset on my cabinet door and about 5mm thick or so. I added pins or studs to it that line up with the screw holes to give mounting accuracy (so the parts are straight!) then super glue it together. so far so good but we'll see.

description.text:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2516411 looks like a great idea for mounting a cam to X axis arm, but the included camera mount will not fit Raspicam v2.1 .. so I made this.

EDIT: I uploaded each as a separate pieces so they could be oriented the way you want for printing with supports.

I wanted to test my ability of designing a cabinet with drawers.
Designed it in Fusion 360.
Updated model with a Claw and wider LED chamber, also extended the chamber so its open on both sides for easier removal of supports. Also made a lid to cover one hole.

Hello,
This design is inspired by a handy spinner and the hexagonal symmetry of the snowflake.
I made them together: I've designed the SnowFlakeSpinner.
The complete model consists of three part:

  1. Base module, it is a simple snowflake with a hole in the centre to mount a ball bearing. You can choose 623ZZ or 608ZZ type bearing. At the end of the six main arms I put one spin mount to place the spinner module on it.
  2. Spin module, it is also a simple snowflake with a hole in the centre to mount a ball bearing. It is designed for only 623ZZ because of sizing. Near the end of its six arms there I put one hex nut (sized for M4 nut). You should put into them nuts in order to make the spinner heavier.
  3. Table mount module, it is a small snowflake with a bearing mount in the centre. You should put the base module onto it.

You can set some parameters in the BlocksCAD program. The radius, the bearing type, number of spinners, and printing tolerance, if you need.
I've commented all the variables and modules and functions in the BlocksCAD program. They help you understand the parameters.

BlocksCAD build instructions:
There is a Main module in the program with one parameter. After the global parameter settings, you only need to use this parameter.
If you plan to create one base snowplate and 3 or 6 snowspin spinning on it, and one base mount, you should call this block 3 times.

  1. parameter="base". RENDER, Export the stl file and print is once.
  2. parameter="spin". RENDER, Export the stl file and print it 3 or 6 times.
  3. parameter="mount". RENDER, Export the stl file and print it once.
    You need 1 base bearing + 3 or 6 spin bearing and M4 nuts 6 times of the number of the spinners.

In addition you can select:

  1. "all". This is for only view the whole model with the there kind of modules incorporated. It is not printable.

I've uploaded the images of the rendered modules and the incorporated model too. This contains the bearings in green colour. The different modules has different colours.

I have uploaded the generated stl files also in more parametrised version (bearing, spin number).

HAVE A GOOD SPINNING!

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

i3 MK2S

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

15-25%

Instructions

You will need 1 bearing for the base and 6 bearings for the spinners. All bearings marked as green.
Then SPIN, SPIN and SPIN....

BlocksCAD on iMac

A comment:
On iMac with Safari blocksCAD can not export binary STL.
The generated ASCII STL is not good for viewing in Thingiview. These files are not sliceable with slic3r.

I really like the original design, but I don't like working with it directly on the workbench and instead wanted to clamp it into my vise. Clamping it vertically puts the jaws in the way, and since the sides are angled clamping it horizontally was less than stable.

author: stoto

title: TwentyFour-7 2" Quad
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Inspired by the RS90, FlexRC Owl and DJ105 enclosed prop designs, I have set out to make a capable 2S indoor and outdoor quad that you can easily create at home, add your own electronics stack and fly without fear of breaking.

There is now a 15x15/16x16mm slot and 20x20mm FC mounting holes on the top and bottom frames. If you want to use an AIO stack, you may need to fiddle a bit to get everything in - especially with a 20x20mm stack!

There are now larger slots top and bottom for the battery strap and the USB port is no longer covered by a standoff.

You can run in a pusher or puller prop configuration (I prefer pusher with reversed prop directions).

My build list:

2mm nylon hardware (x20 M2x10mm)
15mm standoffs (x10)
Racerstar 1103 motors (x4 10,000kv)
Gemfan 2040 quad blade props x4
Eachine Teenycube 15x15mm F3 Flight Controller with PDB
Racerstar 6A 1-2S ESC's (x4)
Runcam Nano FPV camera
Eachine VTX01 Super Mini 5.8G 40CH 25mW FPV Transmitter
Frsky R-XSR Rx

http://amzn.eu/e2BOloX

232° Hotend

Created in Fusion 360 as a learning project.

This is the 5th revision and hopefully final design. The two internal standoffs have been moved fore and aft of the FC stack and battery strap holes have been enlarged on both the top and bottom plate.

print_settings.Notes:: There is no need for supports or rafts.

description.text:
There are probably a thousand and one silica gel bottles already available on the internet, so why not one more?? ;-p

I designed this with a few objectives in mind:

  • The diameter of the bottle (45mm) is designed to fit within a filament spool spindle hole. This is because I store my filament in a round container with the spools laying on their sides. This will allow me to maximise the space for the container.
  • The design should maximise the amount of holes available to expose as much of the silica gel as possible.
  • The holes should be small enough that none of the silica gel falls out.
  • The design should maximise usability (maximise volume of the silica gel, ridges on the cap for better grip).
  • The print should be (sufficiently) aesthetically pleasing.
  • The design should facilitate easy printing (no crazy overhangs, no support structures required, etc.).

Note that by the nature of the design, expect tons of retractions from the print, which can be a jamming nightmare on some printers (I had many many failed prints from this design). If you face a lot of issues with it, try tuning down the retractions. I also realised that there is a bug with linear advance in Marlin if you have a very high K value (>200) where the filament gets retracted on very short lengths (which there are a lot in this design) and result in an almost guaranteed jamming. Try a very low K value or completely disable linear advance for this print if you are facing a similar issue.

Infill:

Notes:

I printed mine in 0.12mm layer height. You will probably be fine in any layer height settings. Infill probably won't matter too much as there is very little infill (the print is too thin for infills).

There is no need for supports or rafts.

author: MacNite

description.text:
In this project students make a stand-up display map of a country. This part of a cross-curricular "culture fair." Details of the other parts of the project can be found in the PDF file.

This is the third year of doing this project with 7th graders.
NGSS

Students create a stand-up map display of a country for a Culture Fair. Full details of the project are in the PDF file, or look at the past projects here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1108998 and https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1852643

Steps
  • Use the Internet to find a map of their country.
    • If they find a monochrome map it can be converted into SVG using a free online image converter. Searching with terms like "clip art," "outline," "silhouette," and "black and white" will improve your chances of finding a suitable map If the map is not monochrome it can be inserted into a Google Drawing. Then use the line tools to trace the outline. After deleting the original map image the tracing can be downloaded as an SVG file.

  • Import the map SVG file in Tinkercad, make the height (z direction) at least 10 mm

  • Add a rectangular base to the map so that it will stand up when printed. Put the name of the country on the base, or on the map. The base height (z direction) should be at least 15 mm

  • If the map is in several pieces (the islands of Japan, for example) connect the pieces to each other and the base with rectangular beams

  • Embellish the map by using the Text Generator or adding shapes that are symbolic or have cultural significance. Images can be imported using the same method as was used for the map. Put the country name on the base or map.

  • Double check that all parts are connected, and the height (z direction) is 15 mm or greater for the base so it will stand up and not be unstable
    • 6.Print your model
  • Color your display with markers or paint.
None

author: Fresh

description.text: This is a small drill bit lathe that attaches to a drill. Small screws are needed to connect the wood to the drill bit lathe.

I wanted to better my tronxy x1's hotend fanduct and add a parts cooling fan.
The hotend fan is now directed at the heatsink only, so the heater block itself doesn't get cooled as much, this results in a shorter warm up time and more stable hotend temps. The circular fang was chosen to cool from all the sides, it works well. Printing with minimal clean-up and easy instalation was a priority in design.

The hardware you need for the hotend fan: Nothing! The stock hardware can be reused if you choose to run with the stock or without a fan cover. If you print one like I did, the 4 fanbolts need to be longer.

The hardware for the parts fan:
4 x M3x30 for 40x40x20 fans or m3x20 for 40x40x10 fans
1 x M3x10
5 x M3 hexnuts

I weighed the total, the stock metal part weighs 80 grams, the pla parts and extra 40x40x20 also come in at around 80 grams.

The benchy fan shield: thing:2763680

Sharing thoughts, results or any feedback is very appreciated!

Printer:

Tronxy X1

Rafts:

No

No

0.2

Infill:

35%

Notes:

For printorientation, see photo's.
I used:
123-3d orange PLA
Gluestick for the bed

0.2 layer height.
30mm/s
195C

No supports
All on the stock tronxy x1

This was a student project for Valentine's Day. It would also work well for Mother's Day. The students designed a heart shaped box with a customized lid. Here you will find a selection of customized lids made by the students.

This was the second year doing this project with students. The original lesson plan and models can be found here: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2057781

Here's a link to the blank bank and top on Tinkercad: https://www.tinkercad.com/things/3yAB57h1Ssj-heart-shaped-box/editv2

I printed the lid face up, despite the overhang. This create a somewhat hairy underside but it's concealed, and the top wasn't affected. If this is a concern you can print it with support. With the lid face up there isn't much surface in contact with the build plate. I didn't have any trouble printing them, but you might need a brim so it sticks.

https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1854908

Coupler that fits inside PVC (or whatever) pipe. Half a coupler, actually, so it can be easily printed and then glued together. This one is designed for a slip fit within 3/4" Schedule 40 pipe, and it has a thin raft-like flange around the perimeter to minimize warping. Dimensions are easily adjusted using variables in the OpenSCAD file.

• If you'll need something other that a 3/4" Schedule 40 PVC slip fit coupling, edit the OpenSCAD file and modify the variables as desired. Grab the software from http://openscad.org if you don't have it. The variables to edit are at the top in the first few lines.
    • pipe_id = the outer diameter of the pipe to fit in the coupler, in millimeters (20.93)
    • wall = wall thickness of the pipe, which sets the diameter of the inner ledge (3.25)
    • gap = the clearance between the pipe inner diameter and coupler outer diameter (1.0)
    • flange_w = width of anti-warping flange, or 0 for none (6.0)
    • flange_t = thickness of anti-warping flange (0.2)
  • Save and compile the OpenSCAD file, and generate an STL file.
  • Print two of them. I used Cura 12.07 default settings, PLA, with 20% infill. 190 degrees. Each took a bit over an hour for me.
  • Trim off the flange with a hobby knife. It should come off easily, a minute or two of effort.
  • Glue them together with cyanoacrylate. If they are a bit warped and don't fit perfectly, heat up the flat faces. I put them in a hot pan until they're just hot enough that they aren't quite sticky, then press them together, and wick the glue into the seams.
  • Use.

The mount itself is adjustable in x and y direction.

One of the E3D V6 3D models of this thing was used:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:341689 (i used the 1,75 mm direct mount version)

2018-02-16
Added the Mk 1.1 version. The mount around the long hole is now more stable (and 1 mm shorter). The fan mount can now be mounted 5 mm higher (it was too low in the original version).
Additionally added the Mk 1.2 version. In this version i bent the mount 5 degree, so the cold air can now hit the printed object better.

I used PETG because of its better heat resistance. (The tip of the funnel is very close to the hot end and nozzle)

Assembly

You will need:

  • (of course) a 40 mm fan
  • between two and four screws (M3 x 15 mm), plus the same amount of hex nuts
  • one screw (M3 x 12 mm), one washer and one square nut for mounting the assembly on the x-carriage.

author: stanciu89

print_settings.Notes:: Print it with the pins side up.

description.text:
My father purchased an Lionel coal dump car off of eBay and the car was broken on arrival. Rather than buying another or returning it to the seller he decided to ask me to fix the car with my 3D-Printer. The coal car is spring loaded and dumps the contents of the car when triggered by the engineer. A plunger holds the hopper in place and is pulled out of the way by an electromagnet in the track. Once the plunger is pulled down, the spring pushes the hopper up which pivots on a hinge. One of the pins that for that hinge was broken off. This caused the hopper to be pushed off at a weird angle when released. I apologize for not having a before picture of the broken coal car.

Using my trusty calipers I replicated the broken piece using Fusion 360. After a couple iterations to get the pin sizes, hole sizes, and distance from the plunger right I had working replacement piece. The old piece is on the right and the new one is on the left.

I included the raw STL from Fusion 360 and one that is scaled to 100% of the real part and rotated in the printing direction that worked best for me.
