author: Lloyd85

description.text:
These "fat coins" can land on their edges as well as their faces. Try out different thickness-to-diameter ratios and search for the fairest three-sided cylinder coin!

These cylinder coins were made for students and classrooms to print and experiment with after watching Matt Parker's video How thick is a three-sided coin?

Ways to get these coins:

  • Download ready-to-print models 20mm-diameter coins with popular ratios;
  • Customize your own coin sets and choose your own coin diameter, popular ratios, or custom ratios;
  • Download the OpenSCAD code from the Thing Files and play with the code on your own computer to make any kind of coin you like;
  • Modify the models in Tinkercad and experiment with other ratios or even other shapes; or
  • Purchase 3D printed sets of coins from our Shapeways shop, if you don't have access to a 3D printer.

Happy flipping!

comments.text:
Hi! I'm trying to participate in the research, but the customize tool isn't working. There's an error that says "/usr/local/bin/openscad/openscad: error while loading shared libraries: libCGAL.so.10: cannot open shared object file: No such file or directory"
If you try to use it anyway and click "Create Thing," the job in the thingy queue fails and says "#<RuntimeError: Failed to get https://www.thingiverse.com/download:4566812 403: Forbidden>"
comments.author: TurtleDynasty

comments.text: Sometimes the Thingiverse Customizer goes down on their end for some reason, I don't know why. But in the meantime you can download the .scad file and open it in the free software OpenSCAD on your own computer. Change the values in the code to whatever you want them to be, then press F5 and you'll see the resulting object. When you have the object you want, press F6 to compile an exportable version. Then use File/Export as STL to save the file. Let me know if you run into any problems!
comments.author: TurtleDynasty

comments.text: Trying to customize one with D = 2.2882456112707374879 (phi times root 2), and it just creates errors. Going to the queue gives 403 errors, and using the "mail me" option just a note that there was an error during generation. I'll look at the openscad later, but in the meantime if you've got a hint about what might be wrong, I'd appreciate it.

comments.text: Looks like Customizer is down on the Thingiverse end, so OpenSCAD is the way to go until they get that resolved

comments.text: I 3-D printed this and from my trials I found 1:e and 1:7/3 work the best. Me and my friends flipped these coins 1000 times each. My bet is on (3*sqrt(e))/2

This is a flat pack bicycle cargo cage designed to fit a large Nalgene bottle or fuel bottle as well as our Stanley Stainless Steel Cook sets. It requires bicycles with triple cage mounts and is printable with a Lulzbot mini.
Print three of the larger cage arms in order to get the most out of strength with PLA.
I printed these at 50% infill to save weight and they have been plenty strong enough.
I've included an .STL to show what it looks like assembled when you print all three of the rounds. See 'VTBADV Cargo Cage Assembled.stl'

UPDATE:
I've added the option to make the VTBADV Cargo Cage so that it can be fitted to a traditional two bolt water bottle mount system. Using the VTBADV Cargo Cage.stl file you can print everything you need in one go on a Lulzbot Mini to mount the cargo cage to a two bolt system. You can later add the third ring and third bolt mount and it will fit directly with this system.

author: boscommx

description.text:
I am always looking for inspiration for my projects and this one was provided by my dad. He recently got diagnosed with tinnitus and got prescribed a set of hearing aids. He has been much happier and is able to hear things he thought he never would again.

However he expressed how often he was replacing the batteries and how they always seemed to go out at the worst times. A month ago he had asked me to make him something he could use to keep spare batteries on him when he is out and about. I had him provide me a few of the size 312 Zinc-air batteries in order to get the correct dimensions.

I spent a few nights planning out a design in my head that would be safe, compact, and easy to access. Came up with this last night and sketched it out in Fusion 360. I was really impressed to see my first prototype print fit together perfectly. Only had to make a few cosmetic adjustments to get this design just the way I wanted it.

I decided to align the torus shaped keyring cut out with the position of the battery tray and added a raised arrow to to make sure it was easy to identify the top of the tray so the batteries would not accidentally spill out while opening. I also used supports between the tray dividers which make them print straighter and adds a little extra material to keep the batteries tight but still easy to pull out.

Thought this was a really cool design and very impressed with the results. Hope you guys enjoy.

CR-10

description.text:
This is a multipurpose mount for your headphones, phone, and five(5) SD memory cards.
The design was inspired by phil barrenger's "Monster Mouth Headphone Holder".
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1657541
Thank you for the inspiration, Phil!
This will clamp to your desk or shelf to hold your headphones, a place to wrap your headphone cord and a hole to keep the plug end (1/4" - 3.5mm - 2.5mm), five slots for SD cards, and a phone stand with charger cord slot for easy access to your phone while it's plugged in.
You can print this with an Apple logo, Android logo, or no logo. Your choice, all files are available.
I also supplied a 'quick print' of the threads (male and female) to see if this will work well for your printer. The thread tolerances work well for my printer, but your millage may vary.

Your desk or shelf needs to be at least 1" thick in order to get a good tight grip with the clamp, but if you find yourself coming up short, you can use the "thread_test-body" piece to add an extra .5".

print_settings.Notes:: I've printed in both ABS and PLA with good results but I recommend using ABS for a few grams less and a bit more strength.

description.text:
For those that want a Runcam 3 camera here is a possible alternative using the Runcam Split version 1. Also made a lower profile case somewhat like the Runcam 2, could be useful on a fix wing I think.
The weight of the case alone is around 30 grams at 30% infill. With M3x16 screws and a voltage regulator(7grams) my fully assembled camera weighted 68 grams.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Clone

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.1-0.2 mm

Infill:

30%

Notes:

I've printed in both ABS and PLA with good results but I recommend using ABS for a few grams less and a bit more strength.

In order to secure the camera and pcb you must add foam(or other soft material) to there holding slots like in the image below. I've used hotglue to stick the foam in place but double sided tape should also work.

Buttons are a bit fiddly, you must Insert them before the pcb and, to keep them in place until inserting the pcb, you should turn the case so they won't fall out. Once the pcb is in place they can't fall anymore. There are 4 buttons in the stl but you only need 2, I've added 2 more just in case some are misprinted.

comments.text:
Great job! That's a very nice looking print and color combination.
While designing I did tried to allow for accessories to be added, problem is that the only accessories that I have are the ones for my Firefly 6S camera and those seems to have a different inner diameter than the ones for GoPro.
comments.author: mg_earl

comments.text:
Great job!
However I would not only rely on the double sided tape to hold the camera in place. In case of crash it may detach and hit the PCB just above. It should be mechanically secured (screws or extend the walls above the camera.
Also, I would add some cooling holes in the case. The Split heats a lot and needs continuous cooling.
TPU material is another option...Maybe with slightly thicker walls.

Positive to pin 1
Sensor out to pin 7
Ground to pin 9

Octoprint setup

Install plug-in "Filament Sensor Reloaded"
Set up the plug-in as per the attached image.

In Octoprint Settings > Gcode settings, use the following for
"After print job is paused"

{% if pause_position.x is not none %}
; relative XYZE
G91
M83

; retract filament, move Z slightly upwards
G1 E-10 F6750
G1 Z+5

; absolute XYZE
M82
G90

; move to a safe rest position, adjust as necessary
G1 X0 Y0
M18 S21600
{% endif %}

Use the following for "Before print job is resumed"

{% if pause_position.x is not none %}
; relative extruder
M83

; prime nozzle
G1 E-5 F4500
G1 E5 F4500
G1 E10 F4500

; absolute E
M82

; absolute XYZ
G90

; reset E
G92 E{{ pause_position.e }}

; move back to pause position XYZ
G1 X{{ pause_position.x }} Y{{ pause_position.y }} Z{{ pause_position.z }} F4500

; reset to feed rate before pause if available
{% if pause_position.f is not none %}G1 F{{ pause_position.f }}{% endif %}
{% endif %}

description.text:
This is a GoPro compatible mount for Original Prusa i3 MK3 3D Printer.
You can watch a youtube video on my channel on the making of the mount here:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ZI6vQh1Lm44

This mount is designed in Fusion 360 and includes a cable management solution for USB power cable people normally connect to the GoPro camera for power.

To Install, remove the removable build plate of the MK3 heat bed, remove the front-left corner screw (or front-right if you print this mirrored) and the metal spacer that is between the heatbed and y-carriage. After clening out a littlebit of drooping inside the part, ( see Post-printing )
Test fit the part on the Y-carriage, and depending on your extrution settings and filament, you might want to use sandpaper to slighly top of the part that goes underneeth the headbed, then push the metal spacer though the hole of the mount and have it flush against the top of printed part and place it in place and secure with the screw removed earlier

After mounting a GoPro or another camera to the mount, fix the powercable in the fixtures, they are a little tight and take care not to damage the cable if your cable is wider than the one I used for reference. If your cable does not fit, you can use a zip-tie to fix the cable to the hole in the bend of the arm, and another zip-tie on the left most gopro mount upright.

This is an articulated fully adjustable heat-gun holder that allows the heat-gun to be move into the most convenient position possible in a fraction of a second versus the conventional nonadjustable holders in the market. When working on iPhones, iPads and other electronics theres a need to apply heat to parts in order to soften the adhesive that keeps them together, without heat this parts may be permanently damaged and will render the devices unusable. The current problem is that if you are working with two hands and the heat-gun is in a fixed location, now you have to take your device to the heat-gun or bring the heat-gun to you; which disrupts the repair flow and increase the risk of damaging the device or loosing parts. With the Articulated Heat-gun Holder you can bring the heat to were you are working in a mater of a second and move it away in the same time frame. More information will be available soon. :-) Please comment on what you think about our gadget. Fell free to leave a comment in our KickStarter project: https://www.kickstarter.com/projects/244303610/articulated-heat-gun-holder

This is an easy to print adapter to add LED's to your compressed air rockets. Allows you to launch at dusk or at night for a rocket light show - plus helps you find it in the dark...
Fits air rockets based on a 1/2" pipe launch tube. Works well with Air Rocket Works compressed air rocket parts: www.airrocketworks.com

  1. Print all 3 parts, Lower LED Housing.STL, Upper LED Housing.STL and LED Bend Tool.STL
  2. Test threads and adjust printer settings if needed.
  3. Locate (3) 5mm LED's and 2 AG13/LR44 batteries.
  4. Bend and trim LED legs using the 3D printed tool. Using the multi-image above, start in the upper left image by orienting the LED with the short leg (adjacent to the flat on the LED) near the top
  5. Bend the long LED leg straight down
  6. Bend the long LED leg to the right to fit in the groove
  7. Bend the upper LED leg to fit in the upper groove
  8. Mark the LED legs between the two arrowheads
  9. Remove and trim the LED legs, then double check length and bends in the tool
  10. Test the LED polarity by checking it across the batteries as shown.
  11. Repeat with 2 more LED's
  12. Install 3 bent LED's along with 2 batteries into the cavity in the Lower LED Housing. Adjust the upper lead so the LED's are not illuminated.
  13. Thread the Upper LED Housing part into place, and adjust LED legs to have it turn on/off the LED's with a twist.
  14. Using superglue, install the lower LED housing into a ABS Body Tube.
  15. Trim and apply sticker fins
  16. Insert foam nose into Upper LED Housing
  17. Turn on and LAUNCH!

Check out our other "launchables", left to right in the third image:
CARB (Compressed Air Rocke Bounce) - Our standard rocket, foam nose, ABS body tube, sticker fins
ARG (Air Rocket Glider) - This launches like a rocket and glides down like a plane
Lego MiniFig Adapter - Launch your favorite (or least favorite) Lego MiniFig with this adapter
LED Rocket Adapter - This project
CARP (Compressed Air Rocket Parachute) - Currently under development

Notes:

And set infill overlap to more than 20%.

1. I saw no problem with screwing the printed part to the filter and it didn't become loose either, But I suggest you to dedicate a cheap and useless UV filter for it and glue two parts together at a desired orientation, preferably with Epoxy glue.
  2. My lens has a 62mm filter size and i have no other lenses to test the other sizes, but they Should be fine. if they didn't, you can use the suggest #1.
  3. It will be hard to get the adapter out with only turning it CCW, you SHOULD first get the filter out and then try to drag it out and turn it, it’s because of the layer’s pattern that make it harder to separate from filter.

You’re doing it at your own risk. I'm not responsible for anything that might happen to your camera, lens, filter, mirror, etc...
The fact that I was happy with the results doesn't mean that you will be too, but I hope you will be =)

If you consider these notes, you'll be fine.
1- Print it with black color, don't try to paint it. If you insist on painting it, don't do it with water based paints (like plastic paint), they will separate and became powder and eventually dust right on your
sensor. Oil based colors reduce the chance of this unfortunate event.
2- Clean your adapter from any burrs with an X-Acto knife or a sharp blade, Don't use sand papers.
3- Make sure your filter is clean and got no dust on it.
4- When you’re going to put your lens back the right way, CLEAN it, you are going to put the dusty part right in front of your sensor!

description.text:

comments.text:
A good macro lens will give 1:1 macro ratio but you can get more magnification with a reversed lens on APS-C sensor(1.5 crop factor), and even more than 1.5:1 on a full frame DSLR, depend on the minimum focal length of your lens.
the depth of field is too little though, as much as 2 millimeter in 3.5 aperture. but you can make it longer by closing it to 8.

print_settings.Notes:: Print all the parts before tearing apart your printer for the upgrade. I recommend replacing the bushing on the x axis and/or the smooth rods (depending on condition). While the x carriage is off of the printer, slide in the smooth rods to ensure only movement is along the smooth rod. If the rod wiggles around, replace the bushings. Also check the rods for any burrs or scratches from a worn bushing.  You will need to get a piece of belt to replace the belt currently on the printer. You will also need to get longer M3 screws (45mm) because the fan duct requires them. All other hardware should be in the "official" E3D V6 upgrade from E3d (not sure what screws and stuff comes with clone upgrades). The only thing I kept for this upgrade is the stepper motor and it's cable.

remixed_from.author: GarzaDB
remixed_from.title: Left handed E3D Titan extruder upgrade for Prusa i3

title: E3D Upgrade for Geeetech I3 Pro X

description.text:
Modified stls, better than before.

I remixed the designs by GarzaDB. I wanted a more secure bushing on the smooth rails. Zip ties will break. So I took the front of the x carriage used on GarzaDB's design and made it into its own part. I also modified it to use with the thumb screw that comes with the "Official" E3D V6 Hot End.
For the carriage itself I found another part which I also modified for better belt clearance, and x-stop arm. I also changed the openings for a better fit of M3 screws and nuts. All openings for these screws are in perfect alignment.
For the fan duct, I made the openings for the screws a bit wider so the screw heads fit into the model. This part is designed to hold a 50mm radial fan
I redesigned the part for the z-stop switch. It needed to be longer due the new position of the hot end of the E3D V6.

Printer:

Geeetech I3 Pro X

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

50%

Notes:

Print all the parts before tearing apart your printer for the upgrade. I recommend replacing the bushing on the x axis and/or the smooth rods (depending on condition). While the x carriage is off of the printer, slide in the smooth rods to ensure only movement is along the smooth rod. If the rod wiggles around, replace the bushings. Also check the rods for any burrs or scratches from a worn bushing. You will need to get a piece of belt to replace the belt currently on the printer. You will also need to get longer M3 screws (45mm) because the fan duct requires them. All other hardware should be in the "official" E3D V6 upgrade from E3d (not sure what screws and stuff comes with clone upgrades). The only thing I kept for this upgrade is the stepper motor and it's cable.

Use this video as a guide for the upgrade. This is where I started my upgrade process. After reviewing the video I incorporated the changes mentioned.

www.youtube.com/watch?v=CjAcpDEUwzc&t=711s

title: Raspberry Pi Zero W case for OctoPi

description.text:
This is a case for a Raspberry Pi Zero W with Camera. The camera module is a cheap chinese clone with the long flatcable.

I tried to use as few metal screws as possible. Everything is printable except the USB connector and the screws for the USB-connector holder. The female type A USB connector I used is from an old computer housing, those type of connectors are also sold on Aliexpress.

Because i made the part for the USB connector separate, it is very easy to make your own for whichever type of connector you want.

The two base parts snap together, no screws needed.

title: Little bathtub tug boat (visual benchy)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Growth for my bathtub fleet. A little tugboat.

I had seen a great 3d picture of a tugs and I couldn't get that out of my head. Unfortunately, I don't know where I saw it. So I tried to draw it out of my head. The model was created on this basis.

Even if my boats are not benchmarks (benchy), you can use them for quality control.

I drew two versions. One with open cabin and one with closed. The highlight of the open version is a variation of Larry the Engineer (Makerbot) as captain. The tug can be used on land, then you don't have to pay attention to anything. However, if it is to be floatable, the fuselage must be printed with two different fillings. Otherwise the boat is too light.

Bottom: 40-50% Infill
Top: 10% Infill

The models on the pictures are printed with 70% of the original.

Update (21.01.2018)
Minor bugs fixed, thanks to Melchiorus

See what might come next

Instagram: https://www.instagram.com/vandragon_de

Support me :)

Although it is a lot of fun to draw boats and bring them to life, it takes a lot of time to research and draw. Especially the 1:1000 scale models are very time-consuming. So I wanted to see if there are any dear enthusiasts among you who appreciate my work and support me a little bit. Thank you for your help :)

description.text:
I was getting annoyed with changing spools, I tend to change colors often. I designed this to be easy to place, have the spools glide easily when in use and sit snugly when idle.

You'll need some spare 8mm rods, and 3-5mm set screws
Print one set of rollers for each roll, realistically this will be as long as are your rods. I just used some old ones I had that were slightly warped and unusable otherwise:)

  2. Print the SIDE BRACES with supports (20%) - and I recommend to print at a 45 degree angle.

remixed_from.title: CRE-004 Cryptic Pattern Leg Prosthesis - Huced Despro ITS

description.text:
This is a modification of Djoko Kuswanto's (crewolprint3d) CRE-04_Cryptec_Pattern_Leg_Prosthesis-joint_cover for attaching CRE-04_Cryptec_Pattern_Leg_Prosthesis-cover_front and rear to a standard 30mm diameter prosthetic pylon. https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2754691

The part is a very tight fit over a standard 30mm pylon and cannot be installed by flexing the part open. A pylon adapter will have to be removed from the pylon to install the joint cover. Most pylon adapters utilize 1 or two 4 mm or 5mm hex screws and prosthetists often use lock tight on the screws. Make sure and mark the alignment before removing so that all parts can be reassembled with the original alignment settings. See picutre for example of 4mm screw to loosen to remove the adapter. Note - look closely for the black mark on the pylon to realign the parts and the prosthetic foot is removed for purposes of the picture.

comments.author: JEFFROPP

title: RifRaf Carcassonne Under The Big Top Game

description.text:
This is RIFRAF Carcassonne Under The Big Top Full Set
Under the Big Top. 20 Game Tiles with animal chips. (not all indicated in Pictures)
Printed on a single extruder printer. No two tiles are alike, all custom made with a “c” inlay and 3d texture to the fields and city floor... There is very little to paint, I used 8 different colors of PLA filament and was very precise in my layering. You can see I had some stringing issues with some filament in the pictures, unfortunately the PLA was not the best quality.
Animal chips printed with a .25 nozzle at 10mm detail in two colors/three sections with two filament changes.
Great thanks to all who went before with their developing this game and the many parts. There are dozens of “pieces” from others ideas assembled and added to here. Without the pioneers gone before us we would not be here today. Enjoy!
The compete Base set is finished here, see Rifraf Carcassonne…the River, Festivals, Inns & Cathedrals, Traders & Builders, Abbey & Mayor, The Princess & the Dragon, Under the Big Top, Hills and Sheep and The Tower in my other posts, over 240 Tiles total.
The Original Set: 72 Tiles
The River: 12 Tiles
Festivals: 10 Tiles
Inns & Cathedrals: 18 Tiles
Traders & Builders: 24 Tiles
Abbey & Mayor: 18 Tiles
The Princess & the Dragon: 30 Tiles
The Tower: 18 Tiles
Under the Big Top: 20 Tiles
Hills and Sheep: 18 Tiles
How I printed: On a Prusa i3 MK2 in all PLA with a base height of .200mm and a layer height of .150 with a 4mm nozzle. 4 Base layers and 3 top layers, 15% Cubic infill with a CONCENTRIC Top/Bottom fill pattern, This is important if you want the same layer divisions and “style”. I printed with a 3mm brim attached to all tiles, I found if I did not I got the occasional corner lift, but it did mean I had to trim the sides of all the tiles.
What I painted: The tops of the farm and city houses..RED, the 6 Volcano and 6 “portal” tiles from The Princess and the Dragon…GREY, and the filled in the garden squares using a toothpick and 4 different paints for the flowers…and the tops of the festival tents…That’s it…(there are 2 tiles in The Princess & Dragon that have the cloisters AND emblems, you will have to decide between painting the cloister or wall top towers)..that is if you print the way I did.
Some issues and tips: This is very important…When slicing in Slic3r sometimes the tiles would not render with the correct number of top layers, for example the roads would only have a layer or two finished and then the fill would show through…or the fields would not have all the layers… for some reason, rotating the affected tile 90 degrees on the plate sometimes a couple times and then reslicing fixed this issue…do a good preview check to examine how your layers are printing… it was a ton of wasted prints for me to work this out.
The very base layer has the “C” cut out, if you make your base layer one color, then change to a different color for the next few layers the filament with just “flow” into this space and it looks like you have a nice inlay…it does not affect the rest of the printing in any way… this is the “poor man’s inlay trick”…also the concentric fill pattern on the bottom gives it the “scattered” look sort of like the original tiles.
The fields have a darker layer under the light green, this adds to the textured look, also the City floor has a Dark brown layer followed by two copper layers for the “cobble stone” look, you can experiment with different color materials for enhance the “3d” look of these areas.
I have not printed all the Princess & the Dragon, Traders & Builders, Hills and Sheep or Under the Big Top…I ran out of filament... .. they look good but if they are anything like the rest of the tiles I will have to go back to correct an item or two.. Please let me know.
The Towers are designed to fit snug.
My Printing and colors: (How you slice will of course change any of these) I used Prusa Color print to define the layers.
For all tiles except the ones with a Cloister, the Cathedrals, and the Abbeys
0-.35 Light Green (The Base color, will be shaded according to the subsequent layers)
.35-1.1 Blue (For the base of the ponds)
1.1-20 Skin (for the base of the roads)
2.0-2.3 Copper (for the underlay dark field color)
2.3-3.2 Light Green (for the fields)
3.2-3.35 Dark Brown (for the underlay of the city floor)
3.35-3.35 Copper (for the city floor)
3.65 -4.1 Pearl White (for the base of the shields and emblems)
4.1-4.55 Blue (for the shield and emblem tops)
4.55-8.15 Khaki (for the walls)
8.15---- Blue (for the wall tops and towers)

For the Cloisters: Same to start then 3.65-9.95 is Khaki and then 9.95 and on is RED
For the Cathedrals and Abbey: Same to start then 3.65-13.40 Khaki and then 13.40 and on is RED

Your choices and colors will vary according to what you deicide.. this is just what I did. Have Fun, Hills and Sheep, and if it works for you please send me a "LIKE"

  • added a very thin wall to the open loop: my first attempt printing this one failed, since the small piece at the open end got loose from the bed and ruined the print.   • "Closed" version with thin wall, reces and snap-notch
  • Closed version for a 4 mm PTFE tube - this version I use in my enclosure

They fit perfectly on my MK2S and MK3

title: Idler pulley for GT2 belt with ComfortFit flange

description.text:
My belts are wearing and squeaking. The culprit is the idler pulley. In RepRap spirit, why buy when I can design and print a new one.

Benefits:
Toothed -> gentler on belt to improve longevity and smoother entry/exit
ComfortFit flange -> smooth profile is gentler on belt edges and eliminates squeaking
Dual ball bearing -> more stable, less wobble and smoother

This is designed to exact GT2 belt profile specification. If you have any fit issues, your belt may not be to spec, such as tooth or pitch line.

You will need two 623 bearings per pulley, such as: https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B01G7L3B74/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o09_s02?ie=UTF8&psc=1

I included two sizes of pulley, a 22T and 24T. 22T is more standard but 24T prints a little cleaner with the larger diameter. Your choice. I am running one of each for testing.

Outside dimensions are 9mm (9.4 with washers) x 18mm diameter. Flange is 1mm so 7mm belt path. GT2 is 6mm +/- 0.2mm typical.

Printing:

You really should use s 0.25mm nozzle or similar. It might work with 0.4 nozzle, but likely not as accurate of fit. I think it is impressive to "manufacture" something to this level of precision at home. Enjoy.

Also need to print 0.05 layer height to get the smooth ComfortFit flange. I included gcode that is dual layer, 0.05 for the flange and 0.1 for the rest. I recommend PLA. Note that the washer prints in the middle so don't throw away.

If using Slic3r, I recommend these settings (already in supplied gcode): 0% infill, limit speed to 20 mm/s for 0.25 nozzle, 4 perimeters, turn off "ensure vertical wall thickness". You can use 'split' to separate out the washer and can scale it in Z direction if you want a tighter fit.

Build is simple:

Print two, press in a 623 bearing on each side, sandwich together, add washers and install. See photo. Inserting horizontal helps keep the washers in place while you slide it in. The washers should prevent you from over tightening, but make sure it spins freely.

I included a test_moves gcode you can run that moves your X and Y axes in a square, X, circle, fast and slow over full range (Prusa bed) to see if everything is well behaved. Easy to hack the file if you want to change.

remixed_from.title: SPANNERHANDS Spool System Wall Mounted Spool Holder & Dust Cover

description.text: Spool case designed to fit with very tight tollerances, the Esun 1kg spools. The esun spools are overwound from the supplier so require a fit with less than a 1mm gap to prevent the filament from despooling off and tangling. Also, I redesigned the lovely Spannerhands design because my spools are kept inside an autoclave with the printer which has an ambient temperture of 80 degrees celsius (for warp free ABS and Nylon printing). This design works for ABS material and a very large printing nozzel (0.6mm is recomended) with a coresponding layer height to match (0.3mm recomended). Check wall thickness behaviour in the slicer to ensure no hollows for maximum stength. Also, bearing mounts are made to be glued together (once installed).

title: Battery compartment for 4x 18650 batteries and its protection and charge control circuit.

description.text: Change the Nickel-Cadmium batteries for other Lithium Ions, in an electric drill. The original battery pack is composed of 12 elements of Ni-Cd (1.2V), providing the set with a nominal voltage of 14.4V. When using Li-ion batteries (3.7V), it is only necessary to install 4 modules. 4 batteries of type 18650 are used, with a capacity of 9800 mAh (depending on the manufacturer). Although the real capacity of these batteries is much lower, these batteries are perfectly valid for powering an electric screwdriver. The protection and charging module YH11047A is installed inside the battery pack.

description.text:
Just in case you have extra 608 bearing pillows lying around.

This mod is likely not an essential part that will make an incredible amount of difference, as the Ender 4 bed movement is well constrained without modification.

However, I had an extra 608 bearing pillow, and the minor amount of movement was bothersome especially as the bed reached a lower place on the leadscrew.

So this part was required.

Assembly:

  1. Attatch to the extrusion with M5 screws.
  2. Attatch the bearing pillow to the part with M5 screws.
  3. Home the Z axis to align the bearing with the mount properly.
  4. Buy more M5 screws.
    Congratulations you have more M5 screws, and a more stabalized Ender 4 lead screw.

author: Sannyshine

description.text:
Very simple elastic band powered toy car.
You will need:
Elastic band
Thread
Glue (optional)

Print Toy Car 'Ls and Rs' and glue together
Print Wheels 'Ls and Rs'
Print Toy Car ' Drive'
Print Toy Car 'Top'

Thread the string through the hole in the roof of the body and onto the Drive part, tie a knot.
Thread the other end of the String through the 'Top' and also tie a knot.
Clip the wheels Ls and Rs into the body.
Roll the 'Drive' wheel anti clockwise so that the 'Top' is now flush to the roof.
Fix a elastic band on the cutouts of the left side and right side of the body, then put it though the drive wheel.

Pulling the 'Top' unravels the drive wheel and winds the elastic band, storing elastic energy within the elastic band. Once you release it the vehicle will move.

Edit/Update: Altered the axle for a more stable print. Made the drive wheel smaller to accommodate larger elastics.

print_settings.Notes:: When printing the shock absorber : use a flexible material with a low infill like 20% to help with compression when crashed .

description.text:
GoPro Throw Pro !

I saw a device on Kickstarter that allows you to throw your Gopro in cool ways but since I love designing and I have the Session Gopro , I thought to give this a try and make it cheaper too ,to get the same views with my Session camera
link : https://www.kickstarter.com/projects/aervideo/aer-throw-your-gopro

-> Any- Mount - Adapter<-
Since we all have different cameras , I designed this mount in order to give the design a bit more versatility and compatibility with any camera that you may have. On the design you will find the bolt and nut used to attach the camera are standard. 
you should print this part with a infill of 35 to 50 %  and at a layer height of  0.15 to 0.18 mm a good bond . The length of the arm where my logo is can be changed so I will add several dimension just in case.  

- > Gopro Session <-

~~ This design allows you to use a wing as a dart or simply attach a parachute.~~

 ~The wing is made of a plastic like cardboard, For the shape I used a sheet of paper and folded it in half then I drew a wing shape . (still prototype but works)

~ The wing V2 is bigger to give me a better stability on the shots and it has been given the dimension as show on the picture because I want this design to be portable making it able to fit nicely in a school bag. 
~The wing V1 is a bit smaller but this one works well in windy condition when thrown into the wind.
~ The white thumb wheels are not necessary , just for convenience but a normal screwdriver does the job nicely . The screws used are M3 x 25mm  .

~ Small zip ties are used to hold the wing in place. I used 4

~ The whole length of the Gopro Throw Pro is 36cm or 14"

~ Over all weight  7.2oz  or 200g

~ The parachute MUST  have a diameter of 95cm to archive a decent speed of 1.86 m/s 
to get a good footage throw it as high as possible 6 to 10m  works well. 

~ For the shock absorber I suggest you print it using some king of flexible material e.g PETG OR Ninja flex . I have tried to minimise the amount of exposure to the lens. I will add more implementations soon . 

-> GoPro Hero 5 <-
~ I don't have a hero 5 but I managed to do a 3d model for it . Around this model I made the enclosure for it. I would appreciate if anyone can test it out and give me some pointers for improvements , I have tried to leave a good gap for a snug fit . I hope you like it. 

Updates with feedback by e522600 :
~Tolerance gap increased to 0.3mm between camera and enclosure .
~ Camera sits flush inside the enclosure. 
~ Hole added for the mode button , I am hoping  this will not put in jeopardy the structure.

BED nut 1 -
The nut  is a m3 but you will have to print it upto a height of 5 mm then place the nut mid print then finish printing ,it gives the part more rigidity . Also you can just print the one with out this feature. BED nut  2

==== Update 01/03/2018 ==
Solidworks files are available for download .If you find any ways that it could be improved I would appreciate your feedback.
Otherwise,
Have fun!
It would be nice to see your Gopro throw flying please do post a picture :)

A tutorial will come soon on my Youtube channel
Mr Jefferson 105 .

Prusa

Printer:

i3 MK2S

Resolution:

0.19

Infill:

50

When printing the shock absorber : use a flexible material with a low infill like 20% to help with compression when crashed .

title: Prusa Dual Extruder Dual Fan X Carriage, Fan Duct, Fan Mounts

description.text:
Note - v2 is here: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:36670 By designing this I wanted to accomplish a couple of things:
  • Ability to mount fan(s) in the front of the X carriage instead of the side, allowing for greater X movement.
  • Use 4 bearings for better stability. I found that the weight of the motor being on the left side of the X carriage tended to tweak that side of the carriage (the front right side where there is no bearing).
  • Ability to have a fan duct that wraps around two extruders.
  • Reverse the way the right side belt/tensioner worked so I no longer had to twist the belt.
    • Updated 7/20/2012
  • Uploaded repaired STLs and repaired Fan Duct SKP.
  • Added Fan Mount Cover in case a fan has to be taken out of commission so air does not escape where the fan was mounted.
Print one of each, assemble as shown. (More instructions to come once this is officially complete.)

description.text:
This is a pencil holder that I designed to clip onto the edge of a craft table. It has 74 9mm holes in the top and a grid on the bottom for pencil alignment. It was designed specifically for Caran d'Ache Colored and Derwent Pencils but should fit most similar pencils.

The edge clip fits the desk with friction and is pretty snug after some testing. Note that this was created for a craft desk with a 15mm thickness. You will have to adjust for your setup.

The top and bottom print separately. The bottom is a simple print with no specific requirements. The nature of the design makes it pretty rigid. The top piece needs a bit more attention. It prints upside down with supports, which will support the clip piece. Once both are printed they will press fit together.

I would recommend printing the top piece with more infill, more top and bottom layers, and more perimeter shells. The main body is pretty strong, but the legs could use the extra support. I used 50% infill, 6 top and bottom layers, and 6 perimeter shells.

You will note that in the photo I have etched a logo. It is 2mm deep and prints really well on the side. I have linked to my design page below where I have a variety of art supply logos if you want to try this.

I am continuing to create new holders in this style so keep an eye out, or let me know of a specific request. These holders are designed for use on a Studio Designs Pro Craft Station.

https://www.thingiverse.com/wwiens/designs

Stamp Preparation

title: CR-10 FANG OEM fan duct assembly - easy & sturdy print
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
IMPORTANT - PLEASE READ:
I have started with improvements. These will be labeled "V2" in the filenames. Currently there are three V2 parts uploaded. These should still be compatible with all the other (older) parts. The current V2 parts are a new carriage plate, with more room behind the hotend heatsink for better airflow, a new 40mm duct remodeled from the ground up, and a new fang (for the stock fan) with more clearance and other minor improvements.

TOO CONFUSING, TOO MUCH TEXT!:

This is a fang mod upgrade, that is designed to be sturdy and easy to print. Much sturdier and/or easier than the other fang designs out there. It is semi modular with different options, and easy to mod to your own liking, since you only need to mod and print the part you want to change, and not the entire assembly. You need 4 parts for this fang model. The carriage plate, the 40mm duct, the carriage plate clip, and the actual fang. If you have other than stock parts, like a 5015 fan instead of the stock fan, you can download the 5015 fang instead of the regular fang. If you own a MicroSwiss hotend, you must download the MicroSwiss 40mm duct instead of the regular one. If you own an optional bed leveling sensor, you can also download those. Also check out the remix section for extra options. Note that i have not been able to test these optional parts myself, since i don't own a 5015 fan, nor a MicroSwiss hotend, nor any of the sensors. Please follow the installation order. Trust me, it is the best way, i've tried an alternative order that others have followed, (hotend + 40mm duct before fang) and that is not the way to go, since you will get frustrated aligning the fang and screw holes, and you'll risk breaking the more delicate parts. For more info, see the "original info" section.

INSTALLATION ORDER (ignore at your own risk):

  • unmount the old fan box or fang design,
  • unmount the hotend from the carriage
  • install carriage plate + clip (+screws)
  • attach the fang to the carriage plate (+screws) (EDIT: make sure the holes are lined up properly and maybe it's best to squeeze the plastic parts together with your fingers while screwing so that the screw doesn't push them apart and snap the plastic parts)
  • slide the hotend + cables from the top, down between the carriage plate and fang.
  • slide the 40mm duct onto the hotend
  • mount the hotend + 40mm duct onto the carriage, from underneath the fang and tilt it in place (+screws)
  • screw the 40mm duct onto the fang
  • screw the 40mm fan onto the 40mm duct
  • screw the radial fan onto the fang (you can also do this before mounting the fang). Be carefull with the tiny screws. I suggest screwing them into the fang before mounting the fan, back and forth moving forward slowly, just to make sure not to force the screws in, so you don't break the plastic and widen the holes just enough. Once the screw has pierced through, unscrew it, mount the fan, and safely screw the screw in again.

All aditional screws used are 3m screws

UPDATES:

1/ added an optional EZABL sensor mount for those interested, feedback appreciated (i don't own one myself). I used roughly the same coordinates as thing:2446196, which needs offsets set to 48 and -11.

2/ the STL for the 40mm fan duct didn't slice properly in S3D, due to the nature of a number of remixes one over the other. Thanks to Daniel Liška for cleaning it up! (See files).

3/ If the plastic plate sticks out ever so slightly beyond the metal inserts for the hotend, it might be best to tighten the hotend screws again after a first print, when the plastic is still soft. To ensure the hotend touches the metal inserts and doesn't start to wobble ever so slightly when the plastic gets heated.

4/ Added a fang for a non-stock 5015 fan. Optional and experimental (i haven't tested this myself, feedback is welcome). I also gave this fang a little bit more (2mm) clearance at the bottom, without affecting the direction of flow. I also updated the EZABL mount to fit with both fangs (the 5015 is a tad wider, due to the wider fan mount).

5/ Apparently, the newer CR-10S has a set screw were the 40mm fan duct comes. Other users have bypassed this problem by taking the set screw out to mount the fan duct, and putting it back later, or by cutting a tiny notch out of the fan duct. I will try to update the 40mm fan duct to remedy this issue, even though it seems to be a minor grievance.

6/ Uploaded an optional BLtouch mount due to popular demand. Experimental, since i don't own a BLtouch myself. Feedback is welcome. I used the same placement as thing:2493610. Coordinates should be -40 & -10.

7/ Uploaded an optional 40mm fan mount for the MicroSwiss, which i remodeled from the ground up. Also experimental, since i do not own one myself. Again, feedback is greatly appreciated!

8/ Started uploading improved designs. As mentioned in the "please read" note above.

9/ added pictures of the V2 design (the orange parts are V2, the pink ones are V1). For those interested in my Ikea mirror brackets seen in the pictures, see https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2783526

10/ all parts have been tested to be sliced with Cura. If you have issues with some files in S3D, people have had succes using https://service.netfabb.com/service.php to get it to work on S3D. Once everything is done, i'll probably make the updated Blender file available as well, and people can export it themselves if they want.

11/ I have not finished the 40mm Fang yet, but there are two users who each made a remix, so if you're in need, please check those out!

12/ I finally finished the 40mm Fang, it's uploaded but not tested. Feedback welcome. Do compare with the 40mm remixes made by other members. I tried to maximize the airflow from the fan into the fang. Supports should not be needed with this print.

ORIGINAL INFO:
This is a fang mod for the Creality CR-10(s) designed to be sturdier, and easier to print. It is also easier to mod without having to reprint the entire model. This is for a completely stock solution, with optional parts for a 5015 fan, a MicroSwiss hotend, an EZABL leveling sensor, and a BLtouch sensor.

The one i printed originally, had a flimsy connection between the hotend and the 40mm duct, where the entire model was being carried and held up. I printed that model in PLA, (which was supposed to be ok according to the instructions) but only a few minutes into a PLA print at 210°, the entire thing started to wobble as well as the hotend itself, since there was a printed part between the hotend and the screws that held the hotend in place, which also melted. Causing the hotend itself to come slightly loose.

I think that 40mm duct connection method was not a good choice for attaching the entire fang design, and wanted to improve.

The way i designed this mod, it not only makes it easier to print (more parts flat on the bed), but you can also decide which parts to print in ABS, PETG or PLA. Or which parts to print with a brim, or with a different infill or speed/heat settings, supports etc. You could still print the fang in PLA, and print the other parts in ABS or PETG. The risk of a failed print is also greatly reduced, since it is broken down into 4 seperate and easier pieces, as well as shorter prints.

Due to the nature of the design, it is also easier to fit the cables through. Since you have to assemble the design after it is printed. You can use screws, or you can glue it together. Do as you see fit.

The Fang airduct and stock Fang fanmount, were taken from the Blender file by Racush. The plate, clip, new/upgraded 40mm duct, 5015 mount, EZABLE mount, BLtouch mount, fins/wings design, the concept were all done by myself. Some measurements were based on different thingiverse files though.

The V1 blend file is included. It is based on the blend file by Racush. Once i have all V2 parts ready, i will also share that blend file.

https://youtu.be/yi9rvjzJ1fE

Notes:

If you print the fang with supports (i did, some people didn't with success) make sure to set supports to "only touching buildplate" so that there are no supports inside the airways. Only inside the mouth. You should be able to set the overhang angle fairly sharp, like 70°. The only part that might need supports, is the cross section in the middle, imo.

I will put this here, this was my response to a question asking about the infill for these prints:

"It kind of depends on the type of infill and how many walls and top/bottom thickness you want to use. Personally, since most of these models don't have many parts that are very thick to begin with, and the difference in print time as well as material are negligable, i printed most parts at 100% infill and 1 wall thickness (to make sure the infill can get into the tiny spaces). Check your slicer, see how much more time it takes for 100% infill as opposed to 20% infill, and how much more filament is needed. The difference is so small, that i just did it at 100%.

Just did the test in Cura, for the 4 parts on one print bed combined, it's:

  • 3hrs 23 minutes and 49gr of filament at 100% infill (pattern lines) with 1 wall.
  • 2hrs 52 minutes and 43gr of filament at 20% infill (pattern grid) with 3 walls.

In which case i'll go for option 1. But it's up to you. Someone used 0% infill, but he didn't mention how many walls he used. Maybe 3, maybe 4? If he used 4 walls and 0% infill, it still took (according to Cura) 2hrs 46 minutes and 43gr of filament. You see, that due to the nature of these models, the gains in time and plastic are so minor, that personally, i'd go for the more robust print."

I designed this in Blender, started from the blend file by Racush (see source). I modded the 40mm fan duct, designed the carriage plate, and connections for the fang and 40mm fanduct. Many thanks to Racush for adding his blend file, this was a huge timesaver. I have also included my blend file.

comments.text: Well, i guess it's different for everybody, but if you had better results with the stock shroud, you should switch back. The fang ensures cooling from both sides equally, which should give a more even result, but at the same time, if you're using the stock radial fan on top, the air has to travel further and is literally divided into two. So for some prints it may not be better. In this case, you could consider adding a 5015 fan (and print the 5015 model) for more airflow. You can find 5015 fans for under 5 bucks.

comments.text:
Thanks for the feedback. The part between the mounting plate and hotend can't really be removed, unless the entire design would become much less sturdy. The right side of the carriage doesn't have any holes to fix the plate onto. There is the clip, but this is also more a "failsafe" than a real anchor point. I also think this would be overkill. The top part of the hotend, shouldn't be that hot to begin with. I also have not had any heat related issues since i started using this, not even with V1. I print PLA hot (210°) and sometimes print ABS (245°).
The fang design itself, came from the original fang model on thingiverse. How i understand it, is that the airflow should be pointed right below the nozzle, and not the nozzle itself. The plastic has to cool off as soon as it leaves the nozzle, not the nozzle itself, which would just have the same effect as removing the fang and printing at a lower temp.
Yes, i've thought about adding nutshaped indents, so far i haven't because i don't want to make the print too complex, and don't think there is a real issue the way it is. If you follow the mounting order, i think adding a nut should be quite easy, but, i'll look into it.

comments.text: For screws, if you want to use them, and I did, you can get some M3x12 at the local hardware store. I bought 4 of them and 4 nuts to go with it. comments.author: DanTexasMan

comments.text:
In the original info, i've stated "You can use screws, or you can glue it together. Do as you see fit." It seems rather obvious that you would need screws if you want to screw it though. Personally, i've used screws from the 40mm fan, which is now only screwed in with 1 screw, but that seems to hold just fine.
As for the tolerances, for they've been snug printed with two different printers (CR10 and A8) both PLA and ABS. Maybe make sure your Z-seam isn't set for "sharpest corner" or the fins of the fang might bulge a bit at the corner, making it somewhat thicker, throwing off the tolerance. In that case you can try to file it off a bit. Though i have to say, this is the first time i've heard about this happening. Unless you mean it broke off while screwing in a screw, in which case you should follow the mounting instructions to prevent this. But from how you are describing it, it sounds like you broke them while fitting the fang, not while mounting the screws.
PS: at what layer height are you printing? I've noticed a difference in tolerances when printed at 0.3 and 0.2mm layer height. Both fitted fine, but one a bit smoother than the other (i think 0.3 was actually less tight).
comments.author: DanTexasMan

comments.text: Ah yes, I do see that now. Apologies. I would plan on screwing it together.  I only meant that you may have suggested a screw size needed to attach the fang to the carriage plate.

comments.text: If your PETG broke, I'd wonder if the temps were too low or if the fan was on during the print. I've noticed with my PETG that it likes a temp of 245C to come out strong, and no more fan than 30%, which is only after layer 4. The design is very strong from what I can tell, and I muscled it around to see.

comments.text:
Thanks for this great work, it's awesome compared to the alternatives.
On the 5015 fan mount, have you thought about rotating the fan 180deg? There is room, and that way the weight is closer to the cross-bar, rather than trying to lever everything (and the mount) away from the cross bar.
One other note on the 5010 fan part. The holes are M4 on the fan, but it prints something in-between M3 and M4 on the fang structure, So M3 is too small for decent contact, and it requires a lot of filing to get to M4 size (obviously it's super hard to drill since it's so thin).
comments.author: phucknob

comments.text: I fear the fan would be right above the bowden tube entering the hotend, and be in the way of easy access. Most other "proven" designs are also mounted the same way.

I realize all the other 5015 fans are the other way round, but you have designed this "fang" mount to overcome the "short comings" of other designs, and this is clearly one. It makes it a lot neater, and put's far less stress on the mounting system.

comments.author: Technopief

comments.text: No this is currently how it is. I've been printing at 210° and i haven't had any problems yet. However the bottom part of the hotend heatsink (the part that really gets hot) is not blocked at the back by the backplate, and should get sufficient cooling and airflow, imo. If you are worried, maybe you can cut out a piece at the top to ensure better airflow.

comments.text: Have printed it, things just don't seem to line up. Is the fan duct that sits on the cold end supposed to sit all the way down on the hot end heat block after the little black set screw? If so, then I have a huge gap between the 40 mm fan duct top hole and the hole for it on the fang. If it is supposed to sit above the set screw, then I dont line up on the holes on the side. Any advice on where the fan duct for the 40 mm fan sits? Thanks.
comments.author: slaterbbx

comments.text: I had to remove that set screw. It comes out fine and goes back in fine after the fan housing is in place. It takes a bit of fiddling to see how the three fang holes line up but they do. Make sure you don't tighten any of the fang mounting screws before they are all inserted. I had to loosen my three times until I managed to have all three in, but its on and printing ATM
comments.author: slaterbbx

comments.text: Could you post a picture, and did you follow the mounting order instructions?
comments.author: slaterbbx

comments.text: I posted a pic in 'Makes' section.
comments.author: ozfunghi

comments.text: Actually it should be sitting with the set screw in a groove that is cut out into the fan duct for the cold end. so you will have to cut a notch for it, if you are below the set screw then it will be sitting directly on the heat block, and you probably wont want that. So I just used a dremel. Also @Ozfunghi , you probably have an older model cr-10. Up until very recently, this set screw was not there. So none of the fangs are designed for it. But this set screw is an issue for the current design as all new Cr10s have it. ( As I am told in the CR-10 group on facebook ) So the "Install order instructions" are not really related to this issue at all. As it is a problem with the design and you may want to mention in the information page that if you have a brand new CR-10 that the set screw at the bottom of the cold end will need a notch cut out for it on the 40mm fan duct at the bottom.
comments.author: adcrane

comments.text: Yes, i have the old model... bummer that they had to change that.
comments.author: slaterbbx

comments.text: Mine is a CR-10s not two months old. The fan is definitely pointing at the heat break, not the block. The set screw sits just inside the fan housing, butting against the bottom of it. I can't take a photo as its printing ATM.
comments.author: slaterbbx

comments.text: @adcrane yes I understand that it would be pointing at the heat break ( Cold end ) but if you are under the set screw, the bottom of the fan duct is probably very close to the "Hot end" heating block. ( That is the rectangle thing with some insulation wrapped around it just above the nozzle ) Again, if you have a set screw you should have cut out a notch for it. Look at the same place we are talking about on this other fang design and see the notch I am talking about
comments.author: adcrane

comments.text: Apparently not. As you can see from this photo the set screw is sitting within the shroud and there is no venting to the heating block at all. All on the heat-break where its supposed to be. Would have posted this but the printer has been in use till now.

This bed leveling print to help many different kinds of skill level 3D molders. Load the print to your slicer, than to printer and then level, easy....

When you start printing this, start adjusting your bed. This print is designed to make many laps around the build plate for best leveling poison.

Helpful hint & Setting:
Set this .stl for your printer
There are no specific setting
Do not let the print run all the way through
Start and stop the print as needed

FYI: you should be able to use this print on any size build plate, just adjust it in your slicer

If you have any question, please ask...

print_settings.Printer:: R1 ABS + PLA Model

description.text:
A simple enclosure I made for an AndyMark "DeCIMate" Gearbox.
Helps keep grease in and debris out.

Printer Brand:

Robo 3D

Printer:

R1 ABS + PLA Model

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1mm

Infill:

25%

Notes:

I recommend printing this part with at least 3 perimeters (inside and out) if possible, especially if you plan to thread into the screw holes on this part.

I used 0.1mm resolution to get a nice finish, but you could probably get away with 0.2mm if you wanted to. On my printer these parts only take about 1.5 hours to print even at the highest resolution (printing at roughly 80mm/s).

Because this part isn't under any particular load, PLA should be more than adequate, though ABS would be fine too as long as you can account for any shrinkage.

Assembly

To attach to an already assembled DeCIMate gearbox, simply remove the 4 screws from the front of the gearbox and separate the two halves (try to keep the motors and spacer pins in position if possible).

Insert the cover between the two halves so that the ends of the cover match up with the corresponding plates of the gearbox. Make sure to add plenty of lubricant to the gears, Andymark recommends Red Tacky Grease, which I recommend packing the gearboxes full of (you can buy it in bulk from most automotive parts stores) as the gears tend to throw the grease off almost immediately when running.

Reattach the front plate of the gearbox and tighten the screws. Make sure the screws still pass through 4 metal spacers as this cover is not intended to replace the spacers or be load-bearing. Note that the metal spacers also help keep the cover correctly aligned.

remixed_from.author: midnightcharger2
remixed_from.title: Armattan Rooster Vtx 45 degree and antenna mount (2 types)

title: Armattan Rooster Axii 2 u.fl or stubby

description.text:
I saw midnightcharger2's Amrattan Rooster receiver/vtx antenna mounts and I also love my Flight Club AXII mount on my PROton, so I decided to try my hand at making something myself.

I did not import and modify anyone else's STL, but I did use the concept from midnightcharger2.

This is my first model. I'm new to CAD and 3D printing. I've only used the 3D printer for 3DLabPrint planes.

If anyone can help me with suggestions or improvements, I would greatly appreciate it!

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

i3 MK2S

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.10

Infill:

20

Notes:

I printed on it's back with the RX antenna holders facing up and the VTX antenna holder on the top.

After a few tries (and loathing supports) I added arches to avoid supports, dropped the print speed to 20mm/s, 100% fan after first layer, and printed at 200C (I tried 190 but the extruder jammed.) I will post pictures later to see if anyone can help fix my issues.

comments.text: What filament are you using that's giving you trouble, and what is the trouble? For this, supports are pretty much a must. With Priline white and Sainsmart blue TPU, I do 220C/60C, with Sainsmart orange TPU I do 230C/60C. 40mms for all of them. Great job BTW, I really like the way it fits on the quad. Just needs to be slightly tighter for the stubby, maybe you could make a different file for the stubby than the u.fl & MMCX?
